b.  At a tower site the design of the buildings and related structures shall, to the extent possible, use materials, colors, textures, screening, and landscaping that will blend the tower and related facilities to the natural setting and built environment. 
c.  In no case shall a tower be located in the front yard, back yard or side yard of a residential lot, or upon property classified as residential under the City of Cleveland Zoning Ordinance. 
d.  Towers shall not be sited where they will negatively affect any historic or scenic view corridors, as designated by the governing body or any state or federal law or agency, or where such towers will create visual clutter. 
e.  Towers shall be enclosed by decay-resistant security fencing not less than six feet in height and shall be equipped with an appropriate anti-climbing devices or other similar protective devices designed to prevent tower access. 
f.  Placement of more than one tower on a lot owned by the applicant shall be permitted, provided that all applicable state, federal and City of Cleveland codes, ordinances, rules and regulations are complied with. No such tower such lot shall be located closer to an adjacent tower on such than the height of the taller tower. 
(Ord. No. 2011-21, § IV, 12-12-2011) 
Sec. 54-22. - Application procedure. 
(a)  General application requirements for all building and other use permits. Application for a building, erection, maintenance/ renovation, or upgrade activity permit for any telecommunications facility shall be made to the City of Cleveland by the person, company or organization that will own and operate the telecommunications facility and/or tower. An application will not be considered until it is complete. The following information shall be submitted when applying for any telecommunications facility and/or tower permit authorized by this article and must be submitted with said application in order for an application to be considered complete: 
(1)  Site plan or plans to scale specifying the location of telecommunications facilities and/or tower, transmission building and/or other accessory uses, access, parking, fences, landscaped areas, and adjacent land uses. 
(2)  A full description of the environment surrounding the proposed telecommunications facility and/or tower, including, but not limited to, any adjacent residential or commercial structures, roadways, and waterways. 
(3)  A report from a qualified, independent engineer licensed in the State of Georgia, documenting the following: 
a.  Telecommunications facility and/or tower height and design, including technical and engineering data; 
b.  Total anticipated capacity of the telecommunications facility and/or tower, including number and types of antennae which can be accommodated; 
c.  Evidence of structural integrity of the telecommunications facility and/or tower structure; 
d.  Structural failure characteristics of the telecommunication facility and/or tower and demonstration that site and setbacks are in compliance with this ordinance and the Zoning Ordinance of the City of Cleveland, and are of adequate size to contain all debris should structural failure occur; 
e.  A definition of the area of service to be served by the antenna or tower, and whether such antenna or tower is needed for coverage or capacity; 
f.  Information showing the how the proposed telecommunication facility and/or tower would provide the needed coverage or capacity; 
g.  The identity of a community liaison officer appointed by the applicant to resolve issues of concern to the city and neighbors and residents relating to the construction and operation of the proposed telecommunication facility and/or tower, including name, address, telephone number, facsimile number and electronic mail address; and 
h.  Identification of the geographic service areas for proposed telecommunication facility and/or tower, including a map showing the site and the nearest associated telecommunications facility sites within the network, including a description of the distances between the telecommunications facility sites, and a description of how this service area fits into and is necessary for the service network. 
(Ord. No. 2011-21, § V, 12-12-2011) 
Sec. 54-23. - Future development. 
(a)  Two-year plan and site inventory. Each application shall include a two-year facilities plan and site inventory including the following: 
(1)  A list of all existing, existing to be upgraded or replaced, and proposed telecommunications facility and/or tower sites within the City of Cleveland. The list must include the following information for each site: 
a.  Land lot and district; 
b.  911 address if available; 
c.  Type of building (commercial, residential, mixed use) and number of stories; 
d.  The number of antennas and base transceiver stations per site and the location and type of antenna installation (stand alone rooftop, building facade, etc.) and location of the base transceiver station installation(s); 
e.  The height from grade to the top of the antenna installation; and 
f.  The radio frequency range in megahertz, the wattage output of the equipment and effective radiated power. 
(b)  If the applicant does not know specific future tower and antenna site locations, but does know of area where telecommunications facilities and/or towers will be needed within the ensuing two years to provide service, the applicant shall list the assessor's blocks contained within the anticipated geographic service area and identify each geographic service area with a number that will correspond to the future telecommunication facility site. 
(1)  Additional information requirements for towers. 
a.  Applicants must identify all existing towers and all towers for which there are applications currently on file with the city. Applicants must provide evidence of the lack of space on all suitable existing towers to locate the proposed antenna and of the lack of space on existing tower sites to construct a tower for the proposed antenna. If co-location on any such towers would result in less visual impact than the visual impact of the proposed tower, applicants must justify why such co-location is not being proposed. If co-location on any such tower would increase negative visual impact, then the applicant must so state and demonstrate. The city will review with special care justifications that appeal only to undue expense and/or to undue difficulties in entering into a lease agreement. The city shall carefully weigh such claims and the evidence presented in favor of them against a project's negative impacts at the proposed site. 
b.  Applicants must demonstrate that they cannot provide personal wireless communication service without the use of a telecommunications tower. 
c.  The applicant shall quantify the additional tower capacity anticipated, including the approximate number and types of antennae. The applicant shall provide a drawing for each tower showing existing and proposed antennae locations. The applicant shall also describe any limitations on the ability of the tower to accommodate other uses, e.g., radio frequency interference, mass height, frequency or other characteristics. The applicant shall describe the technical options available to overcome those limitations and reasons why the technical options considered were not chosen to be incorporated. The city may approve those limitations if they cannot be overcome by reasonable technical means. 
d.  The applicant must provide a utilities inventory showing the locations of all water, sewage, drainage and power lines impacting the proposed tower site. 
(2)  The applicant must provide any other information which may be requested by the city to fully evaluate and review the application and the potential impact of a proposed telecommunications facility. 
(Ord. No. 2011-21, § VI, 12-12-2011) 
Sec. 54-24. - Permits. 
(a)  Permits . 
(1)  A request for a permit under this article shall be initiated by application to the city and handled in accordance with the permit provision of section 54-22 of this article. City of Cleveland, acting by and through the mayor and council, may issue a permit under this section, provided it shall have determined that all of the requirements of this article, and all other applicable codes, ordinances, rules and regulations of the City of Cleveland, have been met and, further, provided that the benefits of and need for the proposed telecommunication facility and/or tower are greater than any possible depreciating effects and damage to the neighboring properties. 
(2)  In granting a permit, the City of Cleveland may impose additional conditions to the extent determined necessary to buffer or otherwise minimize adverse effects of the proposed telecommunication facility and/or tower on surrounding properties. 
(b)  Permit fees. A fee in the amount of $1,000.00 shall be charged for each application. Permits will be reviewed and a decision will be rendered within 45 days from the date of application. Permits will be effective for a period of 12 months. Expired permits will be treated as a new application upon re-submittal. 
(Ord. No. 2011-21, § VII, 12-12-2011) 
Sec. 54-25. - Co-locations. 
Applicant and owner shall allow other future personal wireless service companies, including public and quasi-public agencies, using functionally equivalent personal wireless technology to co-locate antennae, equipment and facilities on a telecommunications facility unless specific technical constraints prohibit said co-location. Applicant and other personal wireless carriers shall provide a mechanism for the construction and maintenance of shared facilities and infrastructure and shall provide for equitable sharing of cost in accordance with industry standards. 
(Ord. No. 2011-21, § VIII, 12-12-2011) 
Sec. 54-26. - Appeals. 
Appeals from any decision of the City of Cleveland, acting through its mayor and council, may be taken by any person aggrieved or affected by such decision. Such appeal shall be to the Superior Court of White County, Georgia, within 30 days of the decision of said City of Cleveland. Any decision by the City of Cleveland denying a request to place, construct or modify a telecommunications facility shall be in writing. 
(Ord. No. 2011-21, § IX, 12-12-2011) 
Sec. 54-27. - Nuisances. 
Telecommunications facilities, including, without limitation, power source, ventilation and cooling, shall be operated at all times within the limits of, local, state, and federal regulations and shall not be operated so as to cause the generation of heat that adversely affects a building occupant and shall not be maintained or operated in such a manner as to be a nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 2011-21, § X, 12-12-2011) 
Sec. 54-28. - Removal of antennae and towers. 
All telecommunications facilities and/or towers shall be maintained in compliance with standards contained in all applicable codes, ordinances, rules and regulations of the City of Cleveland so as to ensure the structural integrity of such facilities and towers. If upon inspection by the administrator, or his/her designee, of any telecommunications facility it is determined not to comply with all such city codes, ordinances, rules and regulations, or to constitute a danger to persons or property, then upon notice being provided to the owner of the facility and the owner of the property if such owner is different, such owners shall have 30 days to bring such facility and/or tower into compliance. In the event such telecommunications facility and/or tower is not brought into compliance within 30 days, the City of Cleveland may provide notice to the owners requiring the telecommunications facility to be removed. In the event such telecommunications facility and/or tower is not removed within 30 days of receipt of such notice, the City of Cleveland may remove such facility and tower and place a lien upon the property for the costs of removal. Delay by the City of Cleveland in taking action shall not in any way waive the city's right to take action. The City of Cleveland may pursue all legal remedies available to it to insure that telecommunications facilities not in compliance with all applicable city codes, ordinances, rules and regulations or which constitute a danger to persons or property are brought into compliance or removed. The City of Cleveland may seek to have the telecommunications facility and/or tower removed regardless of the owner's or operator's intent to operate the tower or antenna and regardless of any permits, federal, state or otherwise, which may have been granted. 
(Ord. No. 2011-21, § XI, 12-12-2011) 
Sec. 54-29. - Abandoned towers. 
(a)  Any telecommunications facility and/or tower that is not operated for a continuous period of 12 months shall be considered abandoned, whether or not the owner or operator intends to make use of it or any part of it. The owner of a telecommunications facility and/or tower and the owner of the property where the such facility and tower is located shall be under a duty to remove the abandoned telecommunications facility and/or tower. If such abandoned telecommunications facility and/or tower is not removed within 60 days of receipt of notice from the City of Cleveland notifying the owner(s) of such abandonment, the city may remove such tower and/or antenna and place a lien upon the property for the costs of removal. The City of Cleveland may pursue all legal remedies available to it to insure that abandoned telecommunications facilities and/or towers are removed. Delay by the City of Cleveland in taking action shall not in any way waive the city's right to take action. The City of Cleveland may seek to have the telecommunications facility and/or tower removed regardless of the owner's or operator's intent to operate telecommunications facility and/or tower regardless of any permits, federal, state or otherwise, which may have been granted. 
(b)  If the owner of an abandoned abandoned telecommunications facility and/or tower wishes to use such abandoned facility or tower, the owner first must apply for and receive all applicable permits and meet all of the conditions of this article and all other applicable city codes, ordinances, rules and regulations, as though such telecommunications facility and/or tower were an unpermitted facility or tower. 
(Ord. No. 2011-21, § XII, 12-12-2011) 
Sec. 54-30. - Pre-existing towers/non-conforming uses. 
(a)  All telecommunications facilities and/or towers operative on the efffective date of the ordinance from which this article was derived shall be allowed to continue their present usage as a non-conforming use and shall be treated as a non-conforming use site. Routine maintenance shall be permitted on such existing telecommunications facilities and or towers. 
(b)  A telecommunications facility and/or tower that has received complete written approval by the city as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article was derived, but which has not yet been constructed or placed in operation, shall be considered an existing telecommunications facility and/or tower so long as such approval is current and not expired. 
(c)  Placement of an antenna on a non-conforming structure shall be considered an expansion of the non-conforming structure, unless given prior written approval by the City of Cleveland. 
(Ord. No. 2011-21, § XIII, 12-12-2011) 
Sec. 54-31. - Penalty for violations of article. 
(a)  Any person who attempts to erect or erects a telecommunications facility and/or tower covered by this article without having first obtained the necessary permit or variance in the manner provided in this article shall be deemed in violation of this article. Any responsible party or other persons convicted by a court of competent jurisdiction of violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of violating a duly adopted ordinance of the City of Cleveland and shall be punished either by a fine not to exceed $2,500.00 per day, or a term of imprisonment not to exceed 60 days, or both. Each day during which the violation, or failure or refusal to comply, continues, shall constitute a separate violation. 
(b)  If any telecommunications facility and/or tower is erected, constructed, reconstructed, altered, repaired, converted or maintained in violation of this article or without obtaining all required permits, or if any building, structure or land is used in violation of this article, the City of Cleveland, in addition to any other remedies, may institute proceedings to prevent such unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, conversion, maintenance or use and/or to correct and/or abate such violations. Each and every day such unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, conversion, maintenance or use continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2011-21, § XIV, 12-12-2011) 
Secs. 54-32—54-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PREPAID WIRELESS TRANSACTIONS 

Sec. 54-51. - 9-1-1 charge on prepaid wireless transactions. 
In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134.2, there is hereby imposed a prepaid wireless 9-1-1 charge as defined by O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134.2(a)(4) upon every prepaid wireless retail transaction occurring within the jurisdiction of the public service answering point in the amount of 75 cents. 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 1, 8-8-2011) 
Sec. 54-52. - Collection of 9-1-1 charge on prepaid wireless transactions. 
Prepaid wireless 9-1-1 charges collected by sellers shall be remitted to the commissioner of the department of revenue at the times and in the manner provided by O.C.G.A. Chapter 8 of Title 48 with respect to the sales and use tax imposed on prepaid wireless calling service. 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 2, 8-8-2011) 
Sec. 54-53. - Administrative provisions. 
The Clerk of the City of Cleveland is hereby directed to file with the state revenue commissioner a certified copy of the ordinance from which this article was derived and amendments thereto, in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134.2(j)(l), within ten days of enactment of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 3, 8-8-2011) 
Sec. 54-54. - Depositing of funds; use of funds. 
In accordance with O.C.G.A § 46-5-134.2(j)(5), funds received by this county from charges imposed by this article shall be deposited in the emergency telephone system fund maintained by this county pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134 and kept separate from general revenue of the jurisdiction; all such funds shall be used exclusively for the purposes by O.C.G.A. § 46-5-134(f). 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 4, 8-8-2011) 
Chapter 56 - TRAFFIC AND MOTOR VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 et seq.; uniform rules of the road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; off road vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-7-1 et seq.; equipment and inspection of motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-1 et seq.; abandoned motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq.; use of speed detection devices, O.C.G.A. § 40-14-2 et seq.; cities and counties authorized to enact ordinances for removal of vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 56-1. - Adoption of uniform rules of the road. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-370, the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq., known as the uniform rules of the road, and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 are hereby adopted for the traffic regulations of the city with like effect as if recited in this chapter. 
Sec. 56-2. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Crosswalk means that portion of a roadway ordinarily included within the prolongation or connection of curb and property lines at intersections, or any portion of a roadway clearly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
Intersection means the area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curblines, or if none, then of the lateral boundary lines, of two or more streets or highways which join one another at an angle, whether or not one such street or highway crosses the other. 
Motor vehicle means every vehicle which is self-propelled. 
Official traffic signals means all signals, not inconsistent with this chapter, placed or erected by authority of the mayor and city council, for the purpose of directing, warning or regulating traffic. 
Official traffic signs means all signs, markings and devices, other than signals, not inconsistent with this chapter, placed or erected by authority of the mayor and city council for the purpose of guiding, directing, warning or regulating traffic. 
Operator means any person who is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
Pedestrian means any person afoot or in a hand-wheeled vehicle. 
Pneumatic tires means tires of rubber and fabric or similar elastic material inflated with air. 
Police officer means any officer of the police department, or any officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic or to make arrests for violation of traffic regulations. 
Private road or driveway means every road or driveway not open to the use of the public for the purpose of vehicular travel. 
Residence district means any street length between street intersections where more than 50 percent of the frontage is in use for residence purposes, or where so designated as such by ordinance. 
Right-of-way means the privilege of immediate use of the street or highway. 
Roadway means that portion of a street or highway between the regularly established curblines, or that part improved and intended to be used for vehicular travel. 
Safety zone means the area or space officially set apart within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians, which is protected or is so marked or indicated by adequate signs as to be plainly visible at all times while so set apart. 
Sidewalk means that portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property lines. 
Slow or slowly, when used in this chapter or on any official traffic sign, means that the speed of a vehicle shall not exceed ten miles per hour and that the vehicle shall be under perfect control. 
Solid tires means all tires of rubber and fabric or similar elastic material other than pneumatic tires. 
Street or highway means every way or place of whatever nature open to the use of the public, as a matter of right, for purpose of vehicular travel. 
Through street means any street so designated by ordinance whereon traffic has right-of-way over that on intersecting streets, except boulevards. 
Traffic means pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles and other conveyances, either singly or together, while using any prescribed lane of travel. 
Traffic control signal means any device using colored lights, sounds or words or any combination thereof, whether manually, electrically or mechanically operated, by which traffic is directed to stop and to proceed. 
Traffic lane means those spaces in a roadway bounded by real or imaginary lines prescribed for pedestrians or vehicular use. 
Trailer means any vehicle without motive power used for carrying property or passengers wholly on its structure and designed for being drawn by a self-propelled vehicle, except those running exclusively upon tracks. 
Truck means every vehicle designed for transporting materials. 
Vehicle means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public highway, except devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-801) 
State Law reference— Similar definitions, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1. 
Secs. 56-3—56-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 56-23. - Duties of the police department. 
It shall be the duty of the police department to enforce the traffic rules and regulations of the city and all applicable state laws, to make arrests for traffic violations, to investigate accidents, and to cooperate with the other officers of the city in the administration of the traffic laws and in developing ways and means to improve traffic conditions, and to carry out those duties specially imposed upon the department by this chapter and the traffic ordinances of the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-802) 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate traffic by means of police officers preserved, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(1); obedience to persons directing traffic required, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-2. 
Sec. 56-24. - Police department authorized to adopt emergency measures. 
The police department is empowered to make and enforce regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of this chapter, and to make and enforce temporary regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions, for the limit or duration of said emergencies or special conditions only. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-803) 
Sec. 56-25. - Obedience to police and fire department officials. 
No person shall willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of a police officer or fire department official. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-807) 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate traffic by means of police officers preserved, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(1); obedience to persons directing traffic required, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-2. 
Sec. 56-26. - Signals and directions of traffic officers. 
Drivers shall be governed by the signals of traffic officers at intersecting streets and at all other times and places within the city. Drivers must at all times comply with any directions of any member of the police department as to stopping, starting, rate of speed, manner of approaching or departing from any place, the manner of taking on or discharging passengers or loading or unloading goods in any place, or directions deemed necessary by any police officer in the interest of the public safety and convenience. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-834) 
Sec. 56-27. - Public employees to obey traffic regulations. 
The provisions of this article shall apply to the operators of any vehicles owned by or used in the service of the federal, state, county or city governments; and it shall be unlawful for any such operator to violate any of the provisions of this article except as otherwise permitted herein. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-808) 
Sec. 56-28. - Persons propelling pushcarts or riding bicycles or animals to obey traffic regulations. 
Every person propelling a pushcart or riding a bicycle or an animal upon a roadway, and every person driving any animal, shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the operator of any vehicle, except those provisions thereof with reference to the equipment of vehicles and except those provisions which by their very nature can have no application. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-809) 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate persons on toy vehicles preserved, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(18); bicycles and play vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-290 et seq. 
Sec. 56-29. - Impoundment and disposition of motor vehicles. 
(a)  Any person, at the direction of the chief of police or a duly certified police officer, is hereby authorized to remove, or have removed at their direction, a vehicle, from any public or private way or place, under any of the circumstances hereinafter enumerated, the council hereby finding and determining such vehicles under such circumstances to be obstructions to traffic or public nuisances. Such vehicle is authorized to be removed under any of the following circumstances: 
(1)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge, viaduct, subway or tunnel, or where such vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic; 
(2)  When a vehicle upon a public way is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic and the person in charge of the vehicle is by reason of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal; 
(3)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon a street or parked illegally so as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic, or left unattended on any public street with engine running or with keys in the ignition switch or locked; 
(4)  When any vehicle is parked or left standing upon any area or portion of a public street in violation of or contrary to a parking limitation or prohibition established by the chief of police, provided, such area or portion of such public street has been posted with an official sign giving notice both of such limitation or prohibition and of the fact that such area or portion of such street is a "tow away" area; 
(5)  When a vehicle is parked in violation of any traffic ordinance and is an obstruction or hazard or potential obstruction or hazard to any lawful function or limits the normal access to a use of any public or private property; 
(6)  When the driver of such vehicle is taken into custody by the police department and the vehicle would thereby be left unattended upon a street, highway or restricted parking area, or other public way; 
(7)  When the driver of a vehicle is reasonably suspected of using license plates or license permit unlawfully misusing a license plate or license permit issued to the driver, or a vehicle is parked without proper license plates or license permits, or with no license plates or license permit or driven or parked with an invalid or expired license permit; 
(8)  When the driver of a vehicle is driving without an operator's license or chauffeur's license which is current and valid, or who does not have such license in the driver's immediate possession, or who drives a vehicle contrary to restrictions imposed upon the license, or who drives a vehicle while their operator's or chauffeur's license has been denied, suspended, cancelled or revoked by the state; 
(9)  When a vehicle is found parked on or so near to any railroad track as to block the same in any manner; 
(10)  When any truck-tractor is found to be parked in any metered parking space; 
(11)  When any semitrailer is found to be parked in any metered parking space; 
(12)  When the driver of any vehicle, or the vehicle which the driver is driving, is reasonably suspected of having been involved in any hit and run accident; 
(13)  When any vehicle is reasonably suspected of being a stolen vehicle, or parts thereof to be stolen parts; 
(14)  When the driver of any vehicle is taken into custody for suspected felony or misdemeanor, or when the vehicle is suspected of containing stolen goods, or other contraband; 
(15)  When any vehicle is parked or stopped in an emergency access lane in violation of or contrary to a parking limitation or prohibition established by city ordinance, provided that such emergency access lane has been posted with an authorized sign giving notice both of such limitation or prohibition and of the fact that such area or portion of such public roadway or private property is a "tow-away" area. 
(b)  The owner of any vehicle so removed and impounded shall be required to pay storage and other costs incurred by virtue of such removal and impounding, regardless of the cause of the conduct necessitating such action by the police department. 
State Law reference— Disposition of personal property in the custody of law enforcement agencies, O.C.G.A. § 17-5-4; authority to remove vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-3. 
Secs. 56-30—56-46. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ACCIDENT REPORTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Accidents and accident reports, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-270 et seq. 

Sec. 56-47. - Records of traffic accidents. 
It shall be the duty of the police department to keep a record of all violations of the traffic ordinances of the city or of the state vehicle laws of which any person has been charged, together with a record of the final disposition of all such alleged offenses. Such record shall be so maintained as to show all types of violations and the total number of each. Said record shall accumulate during at least a five-year period and from that time on the record shall be maintained complete for at least the most recent five-year period. All such records shall be public records. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-804) 
State Law reference— Traffic accidents, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-270 et seq.; reporting accidents, O.C.G.A. § 40-9-30 et seq. 
Sec. 56-48. - Investigation of accidents. 
It shall be the duty of the police department to investigate traffic accidents, to make arrests, and to assist in the prosecution of those persons charged with violations of law causing or contributing to such accidents. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-805) 
Sec. 56-49. - Traffic accident reports. 
It shall be the duty of the police department to maintain a suitable system of filing for traffic accident reports. Accident reports or cards referring to them shall be filed numerically by location. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-806) 
State Law reference— Duty of law enforcement officer to provide information to parties, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-273.1; reporting accidents, O.C.G.A. § 40-9-30 et seq. 
Sec. 56-50. - Immediate reporting of accidents, assistance to injured. 
In case of accident due to the operation of any vehicle, the driver thereof shall stop immediately and render such assistance as may be possible, giving his correct name, address, and license number to the person injured or to any who request such information, and shall report the accident immediately to the police department or the city clerk. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-848) 
State Law reference— Duties of persons involved in motor vehicle accidents, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-270 et seq. 
Sec. 56-51. - Written report of accident. 
The driver of vehicle which is in any manner involved in an accident resulting in bodily injury to or death of any person or total property damage to an apparent extent of $500.00 or more shall comply with the reporting requirements of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-270 et seq. The provisions of this section shall not be applicable when the accident has been investigated at the scene by a police officer while such driver was present thereat. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-849) 
State Law reference— Due to make immediate report of accident, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-273. 
Sec. 56-52. - When driver unable to report. 
Whenever the driver of a vehicle is physically incapable of giving immediate notice of an accident and there was another occupant in the vehicle at the time of the accident capable of doing so, such occupant shall give, or cause to be given, the notice not given by the driver. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-850) 
Sec. 56-53. - Public inspection of reports relating to accidents. 
(a)  All accident reports made by persons involved in accidents or by garages shall be without prejudice to the individual so reporting and shall be for the confidential use of the police department for the records for accident prevention purposes, or for the administration of the laws of the state relating to the deposit of security and proof of financial responsibility by persons driving or the owners of motor vehicles, except that the identity of a person involved in an accident may be disclosed when such identity is not otherwise known or when such person denies his presence at such accident. 
(b)  All accident reports and supplemental information filed in connection with the administration of the laws of the state relating to the deposit of security or proof of financial responsibility shall be confidential and not open to general public inspection, nor shall copying of lists of such reports be permitted except, however, that such reports and supplemental information may be examined by any person named herein or by his representative designated in writing. 
(c)  No reports or information mentioned in this section shall be used as evidence in any trial, civil or criminal, arising out of an accident, except that the police department shall furnish upon demand of any court, a certificate showing that a specified accident report has or has not been made to the department in compliance with the law. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-851) 
State Law reference— Uniform reports and procedures, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-278. 
Secs. 56-54—56-79. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - AUTHORIZED EMERGENCY VEHICLES 

Sec. 56-80. - General operating regulations. 
(a)  The operation of a fire department vehicle, police department vehicle, or ambulance, when responding to an emergency call or when in the pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law or when responding to but not upon returning from a fire alarm, may exercise the privileges set forth in this section, but subject to the conditions stated herein. All other emergency vehicles, when escorted by an official vehicle, may exercise the privileges stated in subsection (b) of this section, but subject to conditions stated herein. 
(b)  The driver of a fire department vehicle, police department vehicle, or ambulance may: 
(1)  Park or stand irrespective of the provisions of this section; 
(2)  Proceed past a red or stop signal or stop sign, but only after slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation; 
(3)  Exceed the maximum speed limits so long as he does not endanger life or property; 
(4)  Disregard regulations governing direction of movement of turning in specified directions. 
(c)  The exemptions herein presented to a fire department vehicle, police department vehicle, or ambulance shall apply only when the driver of any such vehicle while in motion sounds an audible signal by bell, siren, or exhaust whistle as may be reasonably necessary, and when the vehicle is equipped with at least one lighted lamp displaying a red (or blue) light visible under normal atmospheric conditions from a distance of 500 feet to the front of such vehicle, except that a police vehicle need not be equipped with or display a red light visible from in front of the vehicle. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall not relieve the driver of a fire department vehicle, police department vehicle, or ambulance from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons, nor shall such provisions protect the driver from the consequences of his reckless disregard for the safety of others. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-852) 
State Law reference— Authorized emergency vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-6. 
Sec. 56-81. - Right-of-way of certain vehicles. 
All city vehicles being operated by fire department personnel while in the performance of their duty and all city vehicles being operated by police department personnel while in the performance of their duty shall have the right-of-way on any street and through any procession in the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-831) 
Sec. 56-82. - Following fire apparatus prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle, other than on official business, to follow at closer than 200 feet any fire apparatus traveling in response to a fire alarm, or to drive into or stop any vehicle within the block where fire apparatus has stopped in answer to a fire alarm. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-854) 
State Law reference— Following emergency vehicles prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-247. 
Sec. 56-83. - Driving over fire hose prohibited. 
No vehicle shall be driven over any unprotected hose of a fire department when laid down on any street or private driveway to be used in any fire or alarm of fire, without the consent of the fire department official in command. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-827; Ord. of 12-13-2004, exh. A(7-827)) 
State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-248. 
Secs. 56-84—56-109. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES 

Sec. 56-110. - City to provide for installation and maintenance. 
The city council shall provide for the installation and maintenance of traffic control signs, signals, and devices when and as required under the traffic ordinances of the city to make effective the provisions of such ordinances, and may install and maintain such additional traffic control devices as it may deem necessary to regulate traffic under the traffic ordinances of the city or under state law or to guide or warn traffic. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-870) 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate traffic by means of official traffic control devices preserved, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(2); traffic signs, signals, etc., O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20 et seq. 
Sec. 56-111. - Manual and specifications. 
(a)  State routes. All traffic control signs, signals, and devices installed on state routes within the city after adoption of the ordinance from which this section is derived shall comply with the provisions of the most recent edition of the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices published by the Federal Highway Administration under 23 CFR 655, subpart F (23 CFR 655.601—655.607), as adopted by the state department of transportation. 
(b)  Non-state routes. All signs and signals required hereunder for a particular purpose shall so far as practicable be uniform as to type and location throughout the city. All traffic control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law or this section shall be official traffic control devices. Traffic control devices on non-state routes shall be as specified by the city council. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-871) 
Sec. 56-112. - Driver to obey. 
The driver of any vehicle shall obey the instruction of any official traffic control device applicable thereto placed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, unless otherwise directed by a traffic or police officer, subject to the exemptions granted the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-872) 
State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 4-6-20. 
Sec. 56-113. - When traffic signs required for enforcement purposes. 
No provision of this chapter for which signs are required shall be enforced against an alleged violator if at the time and place of the alleged violation an official sign was not in proper position and sufficiently legible to be seen by an ordinarily observant person. Whenever a particular section does not state that signs are required, such section shall be effective even though no signs are erected or in place. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-873) 
Sec. 56-114. - Traffic control signal legend. 
Whenever traffic is controlled by traffic control signals exhibiting different colored lights successively one at a time, the following colors only shall be used and said lights shall indicate and apply to drivers of vehicles and pedestrians as follows: 
(1)  Green alone. 
a.  Vehicular traffic facing the signal may proceed straight through or turn right or left unless a sign at such place prohibits either such turn. But vehicular traffic, including vehicles turning right or left, shall yield the right-of-way to other vehicles and to pedestrians lawfully within the intersection or an adjacent crosswalk at the time such signal is exhibited. 
b.  Pedestrians facing the signal may proceed across the roadway within any marked or unmarked crosswalk. 
(2)  Steady yellow alone. 
a.  Vehicular traffic facing the signal is thereby warned that the red signal will be exhibited immediately thereafter. 
b.  No pedestrians facing such signal shall enter the roadway until the green is shown alone. 
(3)  Steady red alone. 
a.  Vehicular traffic facing the signal shall stop before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection, or, if none, then before entering the intersection and shall remain stopped until green is shown alone. 
b.  No pedestrian facing such signal shall enter the roadway until the green is shown alone. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-874) 
State Law reference— Meaning of traffic signal indications, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-21. 
Sec. 56-115. - Flashing signals. 
Whenever an illuminated flashing red or yellow signal is used in a traffic sign or signal it shall require obedience by vehicular traffic as follows: 
(1)  Flashing red (stop signal). When a red lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles shall stop before entering the nearest crosswalk at an intersection or at a limit line when marked, or, if none, then before entering the intersection, and the right to proceed shall be subject to the rules applicable after making a stop at a stop sign. 
(2)  Flashing yellow (caution signal). When a yellow lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles may proceed through the intersection or past such signal only with caution. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-875) 
State Law reference— Flashing red and yellow signals, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-23. 
Sec. 56-116. - Display of unauthorized signs, signals, or markings. 
(a)  No person shall place, maintain, or display upon or in view of any highway an unauthorized sign, signal, marking, or device which supposed to be or is an imitation of or resembles an official traffic control device or signal, or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic, or which hides from view or interferes with the effectiveness of any official traffic control device or signal. 
(b)  No person shall place or maintain nor shall any public authority permit upon any highway any traffic sign or signal bearing thereon any commercial advertising. 
(c)  This section shall not be deemed to prohibit the erection upon private property adjacent to highways of signs giving useful directional information and of a type that cannot be mistaken for official signs. 
(d)  Every such prohibited sign, signal, or marking is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and the authority having jurisdiction over the highway is hereby empowered to remove the same or cause it to be removed without notice. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-876) 
State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-25. 
Sec. 56-117. - Unlawful to paint street or curb without specific authority. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, whether a citizen or a police officer, to paint any part of the street, curbing or sidewalk with paint of any color, except, however, duly constituted employees of the police department who may paint the street, curbing or sidewalk under authority of an ordinance or resolution of the mayor and city council specifically authorizing the painting or making. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-877) 
Sec. 56-118. - Interference with official traffic control devices or signals. 
No person shall, without lawful authority, attempt to or in fact alter, deface, injure, knock down or remove any official traffic control device or any railroad sign or signal or any inscription, shield, or insignia thereon, or any part thereof. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-878) 
State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-26. 
Sec. 56-119. - Crosswalks and safety zones. 
The city council is hereby authorized: 
(1)  To designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks, or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where in its opinion there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and at such other places as it may deem necessary. 
(2)  To establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as it may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-879) 
State Law reference— Pedestrians' right-of-way in crosswalks, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-91; driving through safety zones prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-98. 
Sec. 56-120. - Speed detection devices. 
(a)  The Mayor and Council of the City of Cleveland hereby approve of and authorize the use of speed detection devices by the Cleveland Police Department in the use of traffic control within the city limits of the City of Cleveland. 
(b)  The Mayor and Council of the City of Cleveland hereby name all streets, roads, or public ways inside the City of Cleveland in which such devices are to be used as set forth in a schedule, which shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk, the traffic engineer, and the Cleveland Police Department. The schedule is hereby incorporated herein and made part of the section by reference. 
(c)  The Mayor and Council of the City of Cleveland may apply to the Georgia Department of Public Safety for a permit to authorize the use and employment of speed detection devices on streets, above referred, and to take an action that may be appropriate to authorize use of the same as provided by O.C.G.A. § 40-14-2. 
(Ord. No. 2013-04, §§ I—III, 5-13-2013) 
Secs. 56-121—56-136. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 56-137. - Observance of rules and regulations required of operators of all vehicles. 
The owner, operator, driver, or person in charge of any cart, dray, wagon, hackney, coach, omnibus, automobile, truck, taxicab, carriage, buggy, motorcycle, tricycle, bicycle, or other vehicle used, propelled, or driven upon the streets of the city shall conform to and observe the following rules and regulations upon all such streets, alleys, avenues, and public places in said city. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-811) 
State Law reference— Required obedience to traffic laws, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1. 
Sec. 56-138. - General rules. 
Any vehicle, except when passing another vehicle going in the same direction, shall at all times keep as near the righthand curb as possible and shall at all times be driven in a careful manner with due care for the safety and convenience of pedestrians and all other vehicles. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-812) 
State Law reference— Driving on right side of roadway and exceptions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-40. 
Sec. 56-139. - Driver's license required. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner, operator, driver, or chauffeur of any motor vehicle to drive or operate the same or permit the same to be driven or operated on the streets of the city, unless the person operating such motor vehicle has a valid and currently effective driver's license as required by the laws of the state. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-815) 
State Law reference— Drivers' licenses, O.C.G.A. § 40-5-1 et seq. 
Sec. 56-140. - Minimum driving age. 
No person who is less than 16 years of age shall drive any vehicle within the corporate limits of the city, except as otherwise authorized by law. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-816) 
State Law reference— Drivers' licenses, O.C.G.A. § 40-5-1 et seq. 
Sec. 56-141. - State license tags. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate on the streets of the city a vehicle for which a state license tag is required, unless such state license tag for the current year shall be so attached to the vehicle as to be visible and legible at all times. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-817) 
State Law reference— Registration and licensing of motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-20-1. 
Sec. 56-142. - Rules for passing overtaken vehicles. 
A vehicle overtaking another vehicle going in the same direction shall first give an audible warning and then pass on the left side of the overtaken vehicle and not pull to the right until entirely clear of it. No vehicle shall pass another overtaken vehicle on top of a hill, or a curve, or while passing a street intersection. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-813) 
State Law reference— Overtaking a vehicle on the left, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-42; overtaking a vehicle on the right, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-43. 
Sec. 56-143. - Boarding and alighting. 
No person shall board or alight from any vehicle, or ride or jump upon the vehicle without the consent of the driver, or have any part of the body protruding beyond the limits of the vehicle while the same is in operation. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-814) 
Sec. 56-144. - Driving while under influence of intoxicating liquors or narcotic drugs. 
It shall be unlawful for any person while in an intoxicated condition or under the influence of intoxicating liquor or narcotics to such an extent as to deprive him of full possession of his normal faculties to drive or operate any vehicle in the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-821) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-391 et seq. 
Sec. 56-145. - Driving on sidewalk prohibited. 
No vehicle shall be driven within any sidewalk area except at a permanent or temporary driveway. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-828) 
State Law reference— Obstruction of sidewalks prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-43; stopping, standing, or parking on sidewalks prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-203. 
Sec. 56-146. - Limitation on backing. 
No vehicle shall be backed unless such movement can be made with reasonable safety and without interfering with other traffic. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-829) 
State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-240. 
Sec. 56-147. - Emerging from alley or private driveway. 
The driver of a vehicle emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall stop such vehicle immediately prior to driving on to a sidewalk or on to the sidewalk area extending across any alleyway. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-830) 
State Law reference— Vehicle entering roadway, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-73; entering highway from private driveways, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-144. 
Sec. 56-148. - Driving past men working on streets. 
All drivers of vehicles, particularly motor vehicles, in approaching work being done upon any part of any street, by either city employees or employees of public utility corporations, or by permission of the city, shall slow down their vehicles until, in passing such work or workmen, the rate of speed shall be within the limit prescribed by the modifying word "slow" as prescribed elsewhere in this chapter; provided, however, that such workmen or the foreman in charge of them shall place ahead of the work or workmen, in such a conspicuous location that it can be seen by the driver of the approaching vehicle, a sign to read as follows: "Men working—slow—city law"; the letters of such sign to be in accordance with the Standard National Code, and preferably to be made of reflector buttons, but if reflector buttons are not used, such signs shall be properly lighted at night. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-835) 
State Law reference— Yielding right-of-way in highway construction zones and for maintenance vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-75. 
Sec. 56-149. - Reckless driving. 
No person shall operate a vehicle in the city recklessly or at a rate of speed greater than is reasonable and proper having regard to the width, traffic and use of the streets or so as to endanger the property, life, safety or convenience of any person or property. It shall also be unlawful to suddenly accelerate the speed of a vehicle either from a stationary position or while in motion; or to accelerate the vehicle in such a manner as to cause any portion of the vehicle to swerve or slide, in any manner; or to drive a vehicle in such a manner as to cause the tires of the vehicle to make a loud or squealing noise; or to accelerate a vehicle in such a manner as to cause any tire of the vehicle to make or leave a black mark upon the surface of the street. Exceeding the speed limits provided in this chapter shall be prima facie evidence that said vehicle was operated in a reckless manner. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-822; Ord. of 12-13-2004, exh. A(7-822)) 
State Law reference— Driver to use due care; proper use of radio or mobile telephone, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-241; intentional operation of motor vehicles to create danger to persons or property, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-251; reckless driving prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-390. 
Sec. 56-150. - Obstruction to driver's view or to driving mechanism. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to drive the same when such vehicle is so loaded, or when there are in the front seat thereof such number of persons, as to obstruct the view of the driver to the front or sides or to interfere with the operator's control over the driving mechanism of the vehicle. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any passenger in a vehicle to ride in such position as to interfere with either the driver's view ahead or to the rear, or to interfere with the driver's control over the driving mechanism of the vehicle. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-823; Ord. of 12-13-2004, exh. A(7-823)) 
State Law reference— Obstruction to driver's view of control of vehicle, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-242. 
Sec. 56-151. - Use of bicycles, roller skates, scooters, skateboards, and other similar devices. 
(a)  Traffic ordinances apply to persons riding bicycles. Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be granted all the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle, roller skate, rollerblade, ride a skateboard, ride a scooter, or any other similar devices on public sidewalks or in city maintained parks, within the city limits. 
(c)  No person shall park a bicycle upon any street or highway other than upon the roadway against the curb or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle or against a building or at a curb, in such manner as to afford the least obstruction to pedestrians. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to roller skate, rollerblade, ride a skateboard, or any other similar device on any public street or highway within the city limits of the city. Persons riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle. 
(Ord. of 12-13-2004, exh. A(7-824)) 
State Law reference— Bicycles and play vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-290 et seq.; bicycles to obey traffic laws, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-291; authority to regulate persons on toy vehicles preserved, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(18). 
Sec. 56-152. - Bicycles and motorcycles; one rider only. 
It shall be unlawful for more than one person to ride at the same time upon a bicycle or motorcycle, unless such vehicle is designed for the use of more than one person and equipped with a seat for each such person. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-820) 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate persons on toy vehicles preserved, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(18). 
Sec. 56-153. - Regulations for protection of the blind. 
(a)  All drivers of vehicles, motor-driven or otherwise, who observe any person in the act of crossing the street from one sidewalk to the other at intersecting streets, using a white cane or white cane with a red end or accompanied by a service dog, shall immediately bring such vehicles to a complete stop and permit such person to cross said street in safety. 
(b)  The protection granted in this section shall be given only to those pedestrians who are wholly or partially blind. It shall be unlawful for any person not wholly or partially blind to use a cane of the kind described in this section or service dog for the purpose of signaling or stopping vehicular traffic while crossing the street. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-825; Ord. of 12-13-2004, exh. A(7-825)) 
State Law reference— Blind pedestrian right-of-way, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-94. 
Sec. 56-154. - Officers may be detailed to control movement of vehicles during private funerals. 
It shall be within the power and discretion of the chief of police, upon notice from funeral directors, having in charge any funeral to occur at the residence of any person, of the time and place of such funeral, to detail police officers to direct the passing of such house by vehicles other than police or fire machines or ambulances, during the progress of the funeral. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-826; Ord. of 12-13-2004, exh. A(7-826)) 
State Law reference— Regulations regarding following too closely not applicable to funeral processions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-49; disruption of funeral procession prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-34.2. 
Sec. 56-155. - Towing of vehicles restricted. 
No vehicle shall tow more than one other vehicle, nor shall the connection between vehicles exceed 15 feet in length. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-833(e)) 
Sec. 56-156. - Improper operation of off-road vehicles. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this subsection, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Off-road vehicle unless the context otherwise requires, means any motorized vehicle designed for or capable of cross-country travel on or immediately over land, water, snow, ice, marsh, swampland or other natural terrain and not intended for use predominantly on public roads. The term "off-road vehicle" includes, but is not limited to, four-wheel-drive or low-pressure-tire vehicles, two-wheel vehicles (including trail bikes and minibikes), amphibious machines, ground effect or air-cushion vehicles, and any other means of transportation deriving power from any source other than muscle or wind. The term "off-road vehicle" does not include any motorboats; any military, fire or law enforcement vehicle; any vehicles used exclusively on airports; all farm machinery, farm tractors, and other self-propelled equipment for harvesting and transportation of forest products, for clearing land for planting, for utility service and maintenance, for earth moving, construction or mining; and self-propelled lawnmowers, snow blowers, garden or lawn tractors, or golf carts while such vehicles are being used exclusively for their designed purposes. 
(b)  This section shall be considered as cumulative to any and all other laws, rules and regulations regarding the subject matter; however, if this section is in conflict with existing rules, regulations and resolutions, then where it is in conflict this section shall prevail and be considered governing. 
(c)  As authorized by O.C.G.A. § 40-7-5, any person operating an off-road vehicle in the city under any of the following conditions shall be deemed to be in violation of this section: 
(1)  Without operative brakes, or without mufflers or other silencing equipment; 
(2)  In such a manner as to make, continue to make, or cause to be made any loud, unnecessary or unusual sound or noise which either endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others in the county, and which is audible to a person of normal hearing ability more than 50 feet from the point of origin of such sound or noise; 
(3)  On any private property without the property owner or his agent being present or without being in possession of the expressed written permission of the property owner or his agent; 
(4)  On the right-of-way of any street, highway, avenue, lane, public throughway, etc., of the county; 
(5)  On the roadway of any street or highway of the county without complying with all appropriate state laws and county ordinances. 
Secs. 56-157—56-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TURNING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Turning, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-120 et seq. 

Sec. 56-181. - Authority to place restricted turn signs. 
The city council is hereby authorized to determine those intersections at which drivers of vehicles shall not make a right, left, or U-turn, and shall provide for the placement of proper signs at such intersections. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-855) 
Sec. 56-182. - Obedience to no-turn signs. 
It shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to disobey the directions of an authorized sign indicating that a right, left, or U-turn is not permitted. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-856) 
Sec. 56-183. - Limitations on turning around. 
It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to turn such vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any street in the city except at an intersection. Such a turn is then permissible only if the movement can be made in safety and without interfering with other traffic. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-857) 
Secs. 56-184—56-204. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - STOPPING, STANDING, AND PARKING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Stopping, standing, and parking generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200 et seq. 

Sec. 56-205. - Prohibited in specified places; no signs required. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or traffic control device, at any place where prohibited by official signs or regardless of the presence or absence of such signs, in any of the following places: 
(1)  On a sidewalk; 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway; 
(3)  Within an intersection; 
(4)  At any place marked by yellow curbing; 
(5)  Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant; 
(6)  On a crosswalk; 
(7)  Within ten feet of the corner of any street; 
(8)  Within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection; 
(9)  Within 30 feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign, or traffic control signal located at the side of a roadway; 
(10)  Within 20 feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station, and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station, within 75 feet of said entrance, when properly signposted; 
(11)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when stopping, standing, or parking would obstruct traffic; 
(12)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street. 
(b)  No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into any such prohibited area or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful. 
(c)  Any vehicle parked or left standing in violation of any provisions of this Code or any ordinance of the city prohibiting or regulating parking or vehicles upon the streets or other places of the city, or for a period exceeding 24 hours is hereby declared a public nuisance and a trespasser on the public right-of-way, and an obstruction upon the streets, and a hazard to traffic thereon, and any public officer upon discovering any such vehicle shall remove such vehicle or cause the same to be removed to any city-owned or operated property where the same shall be kept and detained until the owner of such vehicle, his agent or representative obtains an order from the chief of police authorizing such vehicle to be surrendered, or upon the order from the recorder's court of the city after a hearing shall be had thereon as herein provided. 
(d)  If such vehicle remains in the custody of the city exceeding a period of 30 days, under any one of the circumstances enumerated in subsection (c) of this section, and after a reasonable effort has been made on the part of the city police to locate the owner of such vehicle, then and in that event, the same may be advertised for sale one time in the official county organ and ten days after such advertisement, same may be sold at public sale on the property where the vehicle is located. Proceeds of said sale, after expenses, are to be deposited in the general funds of the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-858) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-203; officers authorized to remove vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-206. 
Sec. 56-206. - Parking prohibited after 12:00 midnight. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park and leave standing or cause to be parked or left standing any automobile, truck, motorcycle, or other similar vehicle on any of the paved streets and in the public square in the city for a period exceeding one hour after 12:00 midnight. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-859) 
Sec. 56-207. - Parking not to obstruct traffic. 
No person shall park any vehicle upon a street in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-860) 
State Law reference— Parking procedure, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200; obstruction of intersection prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-205. 
Sec. 56-208. - Parking for repairs restricted to emergencies. 
No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway for the principal purpose of washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle except repairs necessitated by an emergency. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-861) 
State Law reference— Disabled vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-204. 
Sec. 56-209. - Parking vehicles for sale on rights-of-way prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to park or leave unattended on or within the right-of-way of any public road in the incorporated areas of the city any used motor vehicle that is marked for sale or otherwise displayed for sale. A vehicle shall be considered to be displayed for sale when a reasonable person would perceive that the vehicle is for sale without having to inquire whether the vehicle is for sale. 
(b)  The law enforcement officials of the city are authorized and empowered to impound any vehicle found to be in violation of this section. The owner of such vehicle shall be responsible for all expenses and charges incurred in the towing and storage of the vehicle. 
Sec. 56-210. - Authority of city council to prohibit parking in certain areas. 
The city council is hereby authorized to provide, at its discretion, for the erection of signs prohibiting parking upon either or both sides of any street when such parking would, in the opinion of the council, interfere with traffic or create a hazardous or congested condition. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-862) 
Sec. 56-211. - Reserved spaces. 
Parking spaces may be reserved by the city council for the exclusive, free occupancy of such city and county officials as the council may designate. Any reserved spaces so provided shall be clearly marked as such. No vehicles except those permitted by this section shall be parked in these spaces. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-863) 
Sec. 56-212. - Standing for loading or unloading only in certain places. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of a vehicle to stop, stand or park said vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of a vehicle to stop, stand or park said vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers, or for the unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials, and in no case shall a vehicle block the free movement of vehicles from parking spaces. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-864) 
Sec. 56-213. - Backing vehicles into curb to take on or discharge loads. 
In places where, and at such hours as, stopping for loading or unloading of merchandise or materials is permitted, vehicles used for the transportation of merchandise may back into the curb to take on or discharge loads. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-865) 
State Law reference— Parking procedure, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200. 
Sec. 56-214. - Parking signs required. 
Whenever by any ordinance of the city any parking time limit is imposed or parking is prohibited in designated areas, except as provided in section 56-205, it shall be the duty of the city council to provide for the erection of appropriate signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulations shall be effective unless said signs are erected and in place at the time of any alleged offense. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-866) 
Sec. 56-215. - Motor vehicles left unattended; brakes to be set and engine stopped. 
No person having control or charge of a motor vehicle shall allow such vehicle to stand on any street unattended without first setting the brakes thereon and stopping the motor of said vehicle and, when standing upon a perceptible grade, without turning the wheels of such vehicle to the curb or the side of the street or highway. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-867) 
State Law reference— Parking procedure, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200. 
Sec. 56-216. - Lights on parked vehicles. 
Whenever a vehicle is parked or stopped on a street during the time between a half hour after sunset and a half hour before sunrise, or at any other time when there is not sufficient light to render clearly discernible any vehicle on the street from a distance of 200 feet, there shall be displayed upon such vehicle two or more lamps, one of which shall be on the roadway side and project a white light visible under normal atmospheric conditions for a distance of 500 feet to the front of such vehicle, and one of which lamps shall project a red light under like conditions for a distance of 500 feet to the rear of such vehicle, except that such parking lights need not be displayed upon any vehicle stopped or parked in accordance with other provisions of this chapter upon any street designated by the mayor and city council where there is sufficient light to reveal any person within a distance of 200 feet upon such street. If a red glass reflector is installed in the rear of such vehicle and is in place, same may be used without turning on the red taillight provided for elsewhere in this chapter; but said glass reflector must be of approved design. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-868) 
State Law reference— Parking procedure, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200. 
Secs. 56-217—56-240. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SPEED REGULATIONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Maximum speed limits, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-181; power of local authorities to alter speed limits, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183. 

Sec. 56-241. - Maximum speed allowed. 
Except as otherwise provided in this division, it shall be unlawful to operate a motor vehicle on the public streets of the city at a rate of speed greater than 25 miles per hour, excluding state routes unless otherwise posted. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-844) 
State Law reference— Alteration of speed limits by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183. 
Sec. 56-242. - Reduced speed required at intersections. 
Upon approaching any street intersection, curve, or other place of danger, all drivers of vehicles shall slow down to such a speed, not exceeding ten miles per hour, as not to endanger the life or limb of any pedestrians or other persons and shall have said vehicle under complete control. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-845) 
Sec. 56-243. - Reduction of speed when speed hazards exist. 
(a)  No person shall drive a vehicle on a street or highway at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the existing conditions and with due regard for the actual and potential hazards that exist. In every event speed shall be so controlled as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person, vehicle or other conveyance on or entering the street, road, highway or other avenues of travel, in compliance with legal requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care and caution. 
(b)  Where no speed hazards exist that require lower speed for compliance with subsection (a) of this section, the speed of any vehicle not less than the minimum limits or not in excess of the maximum limits or established as authorized herein, shall be lawful, but no speed in excess of the maximum limits specified in this section, or established as authorized by this section, shall be unlawful unless special hazards exist that might require lower speed for compliance with subsection (a) of this section. 
State Law reference— Alteration of speed limits by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183. 
Sec. 56-244. - Driving at unnecessarily slow speed prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person unnecessarily to drive at such slow speed as to impede or block the normal and reasonable movement of traffic. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-846) 
State Law reference— Minimum speed regulation, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-184. 
Sec. 56-245. - Slow moving vehicles. 
Slowly moving or heavily laden vehicles shall not be driven upon the streets abreast, but one must follow behind the other and keep as near the righthand curb as possible. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-847) 
State Law reference— Minimum speed regulation, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-184. 
Sec. 56-246. - Speed detection device authorized. 
The Mayor and Council of the City of Cleveland hereby approve of and authorize the use of speed detection devices by the Cleveland Police Department in the use of traffic control within the city limits of the City of Cleveland. 
(Res. of 5-11-1992; Ord. No. 2016-14, § I, 11-14-2016) 
State Law reference— Georgia Peace Officer Training Act, O.C.G.A. § 35-8-1 et seq.; authority for use or speed detection devices by local law enforcement officers, O.C.G.A. § 40-14-2; requirements that local government obtain state permit, O.C.G.A. § 40-14-2. 
Sec. 56-246.1. - Schedule of streets, roads, and public ways in which speed detection devices used. 
The Mayor and Council of the City of Cleveland hereby name all streets, roads, or public ways inside the City of Cleveland in which such devices are to be used as set forth in a schedule, which shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk, the traffic engineer, and the Cleveland Police Department. The schedule is hereby incorporated herein and made part of the section by reference. 
(Ord. No. 2016-14, § II, 11-14-2016) 
Sec. 56-246.2. - Permit for use and employment of speed detection devices. 
The Mayor and Council of the City of Cleveland may apply to the Georgia Department of Public Safety for a permit to authorize the use and employment of speed detection devices on streets, above referred, and to take an action that may be appropriate to authorize use of the same as provided by O.C.G.A. § 40-14-2. 
(Ord. No. 2016-14, § III, 11-14-2016) 
Sec. 56-247. - List of roadways for city on-system. 

 
(Ord. of 2-9-2004(2), § II; Ord. of 1-7-2008) 
Secs. 56-248—56-272. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - VEHICLE EQUIPMENT 

Sec. 56-273. - Lights on vehicles operated at night required. 
All vehicles used or operated on any street, alley, or highway in the city during the time from one hour after sunset to one hour before sunrise shall have thereon two lighted lamps not to exceed 32 candlepower, each visible from the front of every such vehicle, excepting bicycles and motorcycles which shall have one such light on the front. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-818) 
State Law reference— Lighting equipment, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-20 et seq. 
Sec. 56-274. - Light dimmers required. 
The operator of a motor vehicle shall use his lights during the prescribed hours in such manner as to exhibit only the dim or short range lights while operating said vehicle within the city limits. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-833(c)) 
Sec. 56-275. - Use of spotlights prohibited. 
The use of a spotlight on a vehicle is prohibited, except that it may be used to illuminate only the right side of the street and for a distance not to exceed 15 feet diagonally in front of the vehicle. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-833(f)) 
Sec. 56-276. - Improper wheels. 
No vehicle with wheels so constructed as to cause dents or imprints on paved streets shall be allowed on any paved streets within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-819) 
Sec. 56-277. - Unnecessary noise, sounding of horns prohibited. 
No person shall make, cause, or permit to be made any unnecessary noise by any vehicle, its horn, or other noise-making device. Operators of vehicles are prohibited from sounding their horns while said vehicle is stopped or waiting for a traffic block to pass. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-832) 
State Law reference— Operation of radio at level audible at distance of 100 feet or more prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-14; exhaust systems, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-71. 
Sec. 56-278. - Use of siren or gong prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for the operator of a vehicle, except an authorized emergency vehicle actually on emergency call, to use a siren or gong. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-833(a)) 
Sec. 56-279. - Brakes required. 
All motor vehicles shall be equipped with two sets of adequate brakes kept in good repair at all times, except that motorcycles shall be required to have only one set of brakes in good repair. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-833(b)) 
Sec. 56-280. - Projecting loads restricted. 
No vehicle shall be allowed the use of the streets with a load projecting more than four feet in rear of the body of said vehicle or more than one foot to either side of the vehicle, unless said load has a red flag at least 12 inches square attached to the extreme ends of said projecting load during the daylight hours, and a red light or lantern securely attached to the projecting load during the night hours. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 7-833(g)) 
Secs. 56-281—56-308. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PEDESTRIANS' RIGHTS AND DUTIES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) ---
