This requirement shall apply to all restaurants, cafeterias, fast food establishments, schools, and other facilities such as churches and medical centers where food may be prepared. All such grease traps shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  All grease traps shall have a minimum volume of 1,000 gallons and a maximum volume of 3,000 gallons, and shall be constructed in conformity with the standard development specifications, standard detail No. S12. 
(2)  Under-the-counter grease traps shall not be allowed. 
(3)  All grease traps shall include grease trap filters mounted on the effluent pipe. The grease trap filters must be certified in accordance with NSF/ANSI standard 46, or otherwise approved by the city. The grease trap filters must be removable for purposes of cleaning. The removal and cleaning of grease trap filters shall be the responsibility of the owner. 
(b)  Each length of pipe shall be marked with the manufacturer's name, trade name, nominal size, class, hydrostatic test pressure, manufacturer's standard symbol to signify it was tested, and date of manufacture. Each rubber ring shall be marked with the manufacturer's identification, the size, the year of manufacturer and the classes of pipe with which it can be used. 
(c)  Under no circumstances shall PVC pipe be installed above ground. PVC pipe shall have a minimum three feet of cover and a maximum 12 feet of cover. 
(d)  Mylar marking tape and detection wire should be installed one foot above all nonferrous pipe and properly connected to fittings and valves so that the sewer line can be located with a pipe detector after burial. In the alternative, 14 gauge minimum stranded solid or braided coated wire shall be installed above all nonferrous pipe and properly connected to fittings and valves so that the sewer line can be located with a pipe detector after burial. 
(e)  Ductile iron pipe (DIP) and fittings shall conform to the requirements of ANSI A21.51 (centrifugally cast in metal or sand lined molds). Pipe shall be pressure class 350. The pipe shall be standard cement lined and seal coated with approved bituminous seal coat in accordance with ANSI A21.4. In general the following conditions require the use of ductile iron pipe and fittings: 
(1)  A sewer line crossing a road under pavement or within the road bed shall be DIP and shall be cased ditchline to ditchline. SDR-26 PVC pipe may be used under streets where the sewer line parallels the street; 
(2)  A sewer line outside the roadbed that has less than three feet of cover; 
(3)  All sewer lines that have greater than 12 feet of cover; 
(4)  All stream crossings shall be DIP and cased. 
(f)  High density polyethylene (HDPE) pipe and fittings shall be made of high density, high molecular weight polyethylene pipe material meeting the following conditions: 
(1)  Inlet connections shall be six inches or greater. 
(2)  Joints shall, in all cases, be mechanical joint (MJ) unless prior written approval is given by the engineer. 
(3)  The design of the hydrant shall be of the compression type main valves and O-ring seal between the operating nut and the bonnet. 
(4)  Openings shall be counterclockwise, unless specifically ordered otherwise. 
(5)  Painting of the hydrant shall be accomplished at the factory with enamel approved per AWWA specifications and shall conform to standard red in all cases, unless specified otherwise elsewhere herein or on the plans. 
(6)  The ground line flange shall be constructed so as to permit adding of extensions, replacing of upper barrel section, etc., without closing off the water supply. 
(7)  The operating nut shall be national standard 1½ inches, hexagon in shape. 
(g)  All dead end lines must have an approved flushing device. A fire hydrant at the end of a line is an approved flushing device. For lines smaller than six inches, a flushing device shall be used equal to GIL Industries' Aquarius or Eclipse Truflo No. TF500 blow-off. 
(Ord. of 5-9-1988, § X; Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(IV)(R); Res. of 3-10-2008, exh. A(IV)(R)) 
Sec. 58-142. - Water meters. 
(a)  Residential. This item pertains to two-inch and smaller water meters (small meters). Small meters shall conform to the AWWA C700 (latest revision) and shall be the displacement nutating-disc type designed for complete frost protection whereas the bottom cast iron caps will yield under normal freezing conditions and thus, protect the interior working mechanism from damage. The bottom shall be enamel coated, unless otherwise shown on the plans. All residential water meters shall be five-eighths inch by three-fourths inch. Manufacture of all materials and assembly thereof for this item shall be within the continental United States and no foreign made meters will be allowed. All meters shall be radio read meters as manufactured by Neptune compatible with the city's radio read hardware and software. 
(b)  Large water meters. Water meters two inches and larger in size shall be compound meters per AWWA C702, latest revision. 
(c)  Fire lines and irrigation water lines. Water lines installed to provide flow to irrigation systems, fire sprinkler systems, fire hydrants, or any other fire prevention device located on the user's property may not be used for any purpose other than for irrigation and fire flows. All irrigation and fire lines installed after the date of adoption of the ordinance from which this section is derived shall be installed using a compound water meter in a meter vault near the edge of the right-of-way. Water lines for potable use or that will return spent wastewater to the sewer system shall be separately metered. All meters shall be radio read meters as manufactured by Neptune (or approved equal) compatible with the city's radio read hardware and software. (Also see article V of this chapter.) Fire lines in existence prior to the adoption of the ordinance from which this division is derived which have indicator meters shall not be required to install a radio read meter or a compound meter, except as provided in subsection (d) of this section. 
(d)  Indicator meters. Any facility having a fire line served by an indicator meter shall use the fire line water only for fire flows or for fire flow tests. The city shall be notified seven days in advance of any fire flow tests. Usage of any water through a fire line with an indicator meter as indicated by the indicator meter, other than for bona fide fires or prenotified fire flow tests, shall be charged a user fee of $500.00 per month. Should any user have, in any six months out of any 12-month period, indicated usage through an indicator meter other than for bona fide fires or prenotified fire flow tests, then that user shall be required to install a compound meter in place of the indicator meter. 
(Res. of 3-10-2008, exh. A(IV)(T)) 
Sec. 58-143. - Meter boxes. 
Cast iron meter boxes for meter sizes five-eighths inch, three-fourths inch and one inch shall be of the Rome-Type. The cover will contain, as a part of the casting, the word "Water" on its surface thereof. The box and cover shall be coated with coal tar pitch varnish and its finish shall not be tacky or brittle when cold. Boxes for meter sizes larger than one inch shall be of the traffic-type, and will, in all respects, meet, as a minimum, the requirements set forth in this section for castings for meters one inch and smaller. 
(Res. of 3-10-2008, exh. A(IV)(U)) 
Secs. 58-144—58-169. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STORM DRAINAGE 

Sec. 58-170. - Description. 
This article provides the requirements for furnishing and installing storm drainage facilities, including reinforced concrete pipe, corrugated metal pipe, catchbasins, drop inlets, manholes, junction boxes, curb inlets, drain inlets, special inlets, iron castings, and headwalls. 
(Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(V)(A)) 
Sec. 58-171. - Submittals. 
The developer shall submit drawings and product data conforming to the requirements of these specifications for all pipe greater than 24 inches in diameter, precast concrete items, and castings. Approval of same shall be obtained from the city before any materials of this item may be delivered or erected at the jobsite. 
(Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(V)(B)) 
Sec. 58-172. - Materials. 
(a)  Unless a certain type of construction is specified by the city the various structures included in this section may be constructed of brick, cast in place concrete or precast concrete at the option of the developer. Rubble masonry may be used only when approved by the city. 
(b)  Iron castings. 
(1)  Cast iron for iron castings shall conform to the requirements of Class No. 30 cast iron of the latest ASTM A48, for gray iron castings. 
(2)  Castings shall be sound, smooth, clean and free from blisters and other defects. No plugging of defective castings will be permitted. All unfinished edges of castings shall be neatly cast with suitable rounded corners and all inside angles shall have ample fillets. Where required or called for on the plans, castings shall be machined smooth. Surfaces shall be finished to such smoothness and accuracy of dimensions as to ensure good workmanship when assembled. All castings shall be annealed to remove internal stress before being machined and shall have the mark number and heat number cast on them. 
(3)  All castings shall be cleaned of sand and scale by sandblasting or other effective methods so as to present a smooth, clean and uniform surface. After cleaning, the castings shall be coated with bituminous paint of such properties that a smooth finish is obtained, that is not tacky when warm and that is tough when cold. 
(c)  Reinforced concrete pipe shall meet ASTM C76 for class II, wall B pipe. Joints shall be tongue and groove compression gasket joints meeting ASTM C443. 
(d)  Corrugated metal pipe shall be fully bituminous coated. Joints for corrugated metal pipe, pipe arches and fittings shall be outside collars or coupling bands. Coupling bands shall have galvanized steel angles riveted near the ends and bolts through the angles to draw the bands tight. 

 
*12-inch and 15-inch may be used only under special circumstances. 
(Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(V)(C)) 
Sec. 58-173. - Construction of structures. 
(a)  Poured-in-place units. Construction details shall be shown on the detailed engineering plans. 
(b)  Precast reinforced concrete units. 
(1)  Holes for pipe. Each unit shall be cast with pipe holes of the specific number and dimensions necessary to incorporate the unit into the drainage system as shown on the plans. In the event conditions during installation require additional pipe for which no holes have been cast, the developer may make such holes provided he replaces or repairs any damaged units to the satisfaction of the owner. 
(2)  Pipe connections. Pipe shall be connected to units with either mortar or 3,000 psi concrete. There shall be no voids between the pipe and structure for the full in the structure wall. 
(3)  Installation. Installation is as follows: 
a.  Precast reinforced concrete units. Such units shall be set to within ;pm; one-half inch of grade on a bed of compacted sand bedding material which is approximately two to three inches thick. 
b.  Sectional precast reinforce concrete units. When such units are used to build up extra depth catchbasins or drop inlets, the joints between sections shall be filled with mortar and all such joints shall be wiped smooth. 
(c)  Brick construction. 
(1)  Brickwork shall be constructed using one part Portland cement to two parts clean sand, thoroughly mixed to workable plastic mixture. Not over 20 pounds of hydrated lime per sack of cement may be added. No retempered mortar shall be used. Brick shall be laid with mortar joints three-eighths-inch thick. The inside of the inlet shall be neatly finished with cement mortar one-half-inch thick. 
(2)  After the foundation has been prepared, the concrete bottom shall be constructed to the required line and grade. After the bottom has been allowed to set for a period of not less than 24 hours, the inlet shall be constructed thereon, care being exercised to form the outgoing sewer pipe into the wall of the inlet at the required elevation. 
(d)  Iron castings. Iron castings shall be installed as shown on the plans. All surfaces shall be accurately set to the line and grade and carefully leveled unless otherwise shown. Castings to be embedded in concrete shall be supported firmly and properly until the concrete has been placed around them and hardened. Castings to be embedded in brick masonry shall be inserted as the work progresses. Care shall be exercised in bolting castings to prevent misalignment or springing of any of the parts. 
(Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(V)(D)) 
Sec. 58-174. - Installing storm sewers. 
(a)  Excavation, backfilling and compaction shall be in accordance with normal acceptable standards and shall be in a neat and workmanlike manner. 
(b)  Pipe shall be inspected prior to installations in trench. No defective or damaged pipe shall be installed. 
(c)  Each pipe shall be clearly marked to show its class or gage, date of manufacture and name or trademark of the manufacturer. 
(Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(V)(E)) 
Sec. 58-175. - Pipe laying—Concrete pipe. 
(a)  Immediately prior to laying the pipe, all projections or irregularities that will prevent the joints from closing properly shall be removed. 
(b)  Concrete pipe shall be laid true to the grade on a bed which is uniformly firm throughout its entire length. If material in the bottom of the excavation is of such character as to cause unequal settlement along the length of the storm sewer or culvert, the material shall be removed below the grade given, to such depth as ordered and shall be backfilled with granular bedding material and thoroughly tampered or otherwise compacted to insure an unyielding foundation. Pipe shall not be laid upon the frozen ground. 
(c)  Pipe, unless otherwise provided or directed by the city, shall be laid beginning at the lower end and with the hubs of receiving ends upgrade. 
(d)  The pipe shall be protected from water during placing and until the mortar in the joints has thoroughly set. 
(Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(V)(F)) 
Sec. 58-176. - Same—Corrugated metal pipe and pipe arch. 
(a)  Corrugated metal pipe or pipe arch shall be laid true to line and grades on a bed which is uniformly firm throughout its entire length. 
(b)  Pipes shall be laid only on a foundation which is essentially free of water. 
(c)  The ends of sections shall be fully and closely jointed according to applicable standards and true to the lines and grades given. Each section or joint of pipe shall be securely attached to the adjoining section or joint of pipe with connecting bands or other approved type of joint. The bands or other type of joint shall be tightly drawn or connected so as to form a rigid joint. 
(d)  Any breaks in the bitumen or treatment of bituminous coated pipe shall be refilled with the type and kind of bitumen used in coating the pipe originally. 
(e)  The ends of pipe shall be rigidly supported to prevent any movement pending and during the construction of end supports. 
(f)  Any pipe which is not in true alignment or which shows any settlement after laying or is damaged shall be taken up and relaid. 
(Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(V)(G)) 
Sec. 58-177. - Riprap. 
(a)  All stone for riprap shall be sound, durable pieces meeting the quality requirements of class "A" or "B" coarse aggregate and shall be resistant for use as riprap. Materials not meeting these requirements shall not be used unless approved by petrographic analysis. Flat, slabby, and shaley pieces are not acceptable. Stone for riprap shall be one of the following as called for on the plans: 
(1)  Stone dumped riprap. Stone for dumped riprap shall be processed in such a manner as to produce a quarry-run material including rock fines which will meet the gradation for the following two types: 
a.  Type 1. For severe drainage conditions or moderate wave action: The largest pieces of material shall have a maximum of two cubic feet. At least 35 percent of the mass shall be comprised of pieces which weigh 125 pounds or more. 
b.  Type 3. For general use normal drainage conditions the largest pieces of material shall have a maximum approximate volume of one cubic foot. At least 35 percent of the mass shall be comprised of pieces which weight 15 pounds or more. 
c.  The remainder of Type 1 or 3 shall be well-graded down to the finest sizes. Rock fines shall comprise a maximum of ten percent of the total mass. Rock fines are defined as material passing through a No. 4 sieve. 
(2)  Stone for plain riprap (dumped and hand-placed). Stone for plain riprap shall be clean and essentially free of rock dust and fines. The material shall be processed such that the larges pieces have a volume of not more than two cubic feet and not more than ten percent of the total weight of riprap shall consist of spalls passing a five-inch sieve. 
(b)  Installation of riprap shall be either stone dumped, dumped and hand-placed, or cement grouted as called for on the plans. 
(Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(V)(H)) 
Secs. 58-178—58-206. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BACKFLOW PREVENTION 

Sec. 58-207. - Definitions. 
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article, unless otherwise specifically stated: 
Air gap means the unobstructed vertical distance through the free atmosphere between the lowest opening from any pipe or faucet supplying water to a tank, plumbing fixture, or other device, and the flood level rim of the receptacle. 
Auxiliary water supply means any water supply on, or available to, the premises other than the purveyor's approved public potable water supply. These auxiliary waters may include water from purveyor's public potable water supply or any natural resource such as a well, spring, river, stream, pond, etc., or used water industrial fluids. They may be polluted or contaminated therein being objectionable and constituting an unacceptable water source over which the water purveyor does not have sanitary control. 
Backflow preventer means a device or means to prevent backflow or back-siphonage through a cross connection. 
Backflow preventer assemblies means and includes an approved backflow prevention device, approved isolation valves, and test cocks. For fire lines, the backflow preventer assemblies shall also include a flow detection meter. 
Contaminant means a toxic substance that, if introduced into the potable water supply, would create a health hazard. 
Cross connection means a physical connection or arrangement between two otherwise separate piping systems, one of which contains potable water, the other a nonpotable fluid. 
Cross connection control (CCC) means a general term applied to a program, an ordinance, a code, etc., designed to discover, eliminate, prevent, etc., all cross connection, existing or potential. 
Cross connection control by containment means the installation of a backflow preventer at the service connection to a premises to protect the water main (secondary protection). 
Cross connection control by isolation means the installation of a backflow preventer or a vacuum breaker at the source (point) of each cross connection on a premises to protect both the premises and main (primary protection). 
Cross connection, nonpressure type, means a low inlet installation where a potable water supply pipe is connected or extended below the overflow rim of a receptacle or an environment that contains a nonpotable fluid and is at atmospheric pressure. 
Cross connection, pressure type, means a low inlet installation where a potable water supply is connected to a closed vessel or a piping system that contains nonpotable fluid and is above atmospheric pressure. 
Double check valve assembly means an assembly of at least two independently acting approved check valves. 
Fire lines means water pipes which deliver water to a customer for the sole purpose of suppressing fires. Such flow of water through fire lines is not metered and billed monthly as is water used through nonfire lines. 
Manager of the water system means the city employee who serves as the public works supervisor, who is vested with the authority and responsibility for the implementation of an effective backflow and cross connection control program and for the enforcement of this article. 
Nonresidential user means all users other than residential users. 
Open water supply system means one with no checking device installed in the service pipe and water from the customer's system is free to backflow into the main. 
Pollutant means a nontoxic substance that, if introduced into the potable water system, would be objectionable but would not create a health hazard. 
Reduced pressure principle or approved reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device means a device that consists of two spring-loaded, independently acting, check valves with an intermediate or reduced pressure zone draining to the atmosphere by an independently acting relief valve. The unit operates on the hydraulic principle that water will not flow from a zone of lower pressure to a zone of higher pressure. 
Residential user means a water customer whose water service connection serves a residential unit or units in which people dwell and where no commercial or industrial activities take place on the premises. 
Vacuum breaker (VB) means a general term applied to a back-siphonage prevention device that introduces air into the potable water system when the system pressure approaches zero pounds per square inch (psi). It is designed for use where the receptacle or environment being served is subject to atmospheric pressure only. 
Vacuum breaker, anti-siphon, atmospheric type (VB-AT) means a vacuum breaker designed for use under flow conditions only, not to exceed 24 consecutive hours, and where it will be subject to no static pressure and no back pressure. 
Vacuum breaker, anti-siphon, pressure type (VB PT) means a vacuum breaker designed to operate under continuous pressure, static or flowing, but no back pressure. 
Vacuum breaker, anti-siphon, hose type (VB-HT) means a vacuum breaker designed for hose connection only. It is not approved for continuous pressure, static or flowing. 
Vacuum relief valve means a device to limit the degrees of vacuum in a vessel or pipe. It is neither approved nor designed for use as a cross connection control device. 
(Ord. of 7-8-1996, § II; Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(VI)(II)) 
Sec. 58-208. - Penalties. 
Violations of the provisions of this article shall be subject to the following penalties: 
(1)  Any person, business or company who fails to: 
a.  Install a proper backflow preventer assembly or assemblies in accordance with the provisions herein within 60 days, following proper notification from the manager, shall pay a penalty of $100.00. 
b.  Install a proper backflow preventer assembly or assemblies in accordance with the provisions herein within 90 days, following proper notification from the manager, shall pay a penalty of $500.00. 
c.  Install a proper backflow preventer assembly or assemblies in accordance with the provisions herein within 120 days, following proper notification from the manager, shall pay a penalty of $5,000.00. 
d.  Pay any monetary penalty provided herein within 30 days of notification of the penalty being due, or who fails to install a proper backflow preventer assembly or assemblies in accordance with the provisions herein within six months following proper notification from the manager shall have their water service terminated. 
(2)  Any person, business or company who uses water through a fire line or fire lines for purposes other than the suppression of fire shall be penalized as follows: 

 
(Ord. of 7-8-1996, § X; Ord. of 7-8-1996, § X; Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(VI)(X)) 
Sec. 58-209. - Required; general requirements. 
(a)  All water service connections must have a backflow prevention device in accordance with this article. 
(b)  Any deviation from these specifications or the city's standard details must be approved in writing by the city prior to the start of installation. 
(c)  All assemblies must be installed as near as possible to the water meter/main. 
(d)  All four test cock fittings must have either brassed plugs, plastic plugs, or plastic caps installed. 
(e)  Galvanized nipples and fittings may not be installed directly into/onto an assembly unless a dielectric/insulation fitting is used to separate the dissimilar metals. 
(f)  All assemblies must be tested by a certified backflow prevention assembly tester at the time of installation, prior to obtaining the final city inspection for acceptance. Thereafter, all assemblies must be tested annually. 
(Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(VI)(A)) 
Sec. 58-210. - Meter boxes. 
(a)  Cast iron or HDPE meter boxes may be used for the installation of two inches and smaller assemblies to long as adequate access is available for maintenance and testing. The minimum acceptable dimensions at the base of the box are 27 inches by 40 inches. If the meter box is to be set in concrete, asphalt, and/or in an area subject to other than foot traffic, the meter box must be designed for such an installation. 
(b)  The assembly must be centered in the meter box eight inches to 18 inches deep, from device to top of meter box. 
(c)  There must be a minimum of six inches of gravel covering the entire bottom of the meter box, with six inches of clearance beneath the assembly above the gravel. Mud, dirt, debris, etc., may not be left in the meter box. If the service line is at a depth that warrants an adjustment, complete courses of bricks or concrete blocks, properly mortared in place, or a commercial meter box riser may be used in order to properly support the meter box and to bring the meter box top level with grade. The meter box cannot rest directly on the water line. Pipe cutout holes must be sealed. 
(Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(VI)(B)) 
Sec. 58-211. - Underground vaults for BFP systems having no discharge. 
(a)  Unless otherwise approved by the city, the attached vault detail sheets for specifications pertaining to the proper installation of all 2½ inches and larger assemblies in precast, reinforced concrete vaults must be followed. A complete package precast vault such as the one offered by Tindall Concrete that has a backflow prevention assembly already installed, or one that is its equal is acceptable. 
(b)  All 2½ inches and larger assemblies must be supported with commercial pipe supports, as shown on the attached vault detail sheets. Concrete blocks, bricks, pieces of wood, etc., are not acceptable. 
(Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(VI)(C)) 
Sec. 58-212. - Aboveground enclosures for BFP systems which have a discharge, e.g., RPZs. 
All BFP systems which discharge shall be installed aboveground. Such above ground installations shall be covered and insulated to prevent freezing. Enclosures shall have a removable top and/or side panels to allow access for testing and repair. All aboveground assemblies shall have a positive drain located above grade. All aboveground enclosures shall be bolted to a concrete base pad which extends four inches beyond the edges of the enclosure. 
(Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(VI)(D)) 
Sec. 58-213. - Interior. 
Prior to a backflow prevention assembly being installed inside a building or any structure for the purpose of isolating a service connection from the city's water main, approval in the form of a written variance pertaining to the reason, the assembly's exact location and method of installation must be obtained from the city. 
(Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(VI)(E)) 
Sec. 58-214. - Notice of closed system. 
(a)  Installation of a backflow prevention assembly on a service line creates a closed system. An auxiliary relief valve or an expansion chamber should be installed to allow for thermal expansion as pursuant to the city's standard detail. 
(b)  The city accepts no responsibility or liability pertaining to any backflow prevention assembly being properly installed, tested, maintained, serviced, or operating properly. Full responsibility and liability is that of the owner. 
(c)  Information regarding backflow prevention assemblies may be obtained from the city backflow prevention inspector. 
(Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(VI)(F)) 
Sec. 58-215. - Cross connection. 
(a)  Responsibility. The water system manager, or his designee, shall be responsible for the protection of the public potable water distribution system from contamination due to backflow or back-siphonage of contaminants or pollutants through the water service connections, and for the administration of this article. 
(1)  If, in the judgment of said manager or his designee, an approved backflow prevention device is required at the city's service connection to any customer's premises, the manager, or his designee, shall give notice, in writing, to said customer to install such an approved backflow preventer assembly at each service connection to the premises. 
(2)  Upon notification by the manager, the customer being so notified shall install an approved backflow preventer assembly as provided herein within the time frames provided in subsection (a)(4) of this section. Failure to install such a backflow preventer assembly within the time frames provided shall result in penalties as set forth in section 58-208. 
(3)  Four classes of customers for purposes of regulating back prevention are provided, as follows: 
a.  Class I. All fire service lines which are designed and intended for suppression of fires. 
b.  Class II. All hospitals, medical service centers, doctor's offices, funeral homes, dental offices, industries, wood treatment companies, pesticide or pest control businesses, printing or photographic development companies, fertilizer companies, and all water customers (residential and nonresidential) who have auxiliary water supplies. 
c.  Class III. All nonresidential users not otherwise included in Classes I or II of subsections (a)(3)a and b of this section. 
d.  Class IV. All residential users not otherwise included in Class II of subsection (a)(3)b of this section. 
(4)  The following implementation goals are provided for all users within each class: 

 
(5)  Notification implementation. It is the intention of the city for all water customers of the city to have backflow preventer assemblies installed, with the greater emphasis being on the higher class categories. All new water service connections following the adoption of this article shall have a backflow preventer assembly installed in accordance with the provisions herein. Existing water customers shall be notified by the manager of the need to install such a backflow preventer assembly. Upon such notice, the customer shall have 60 days from receipt of said notice to install a proper backflow preventer assembly, or assemblies, as provided herein. 
(6)  Unauthorized water use. Except for fire lines, all water used by water system customers shall pass through metered water lines. Unmetered water may be used through fire lines only for the purpose of suppressing fires. The unauthorized use of water through fire lines shall be penalized as set forth in section 58-208. Testing of fire line is not an unauthorized water use so long as: 
a.  The manager is notified of the test seven days prior to the test; 
b.  The manager is informed as to the volume of water used for the test; and 
c.  The user conducts no more than two tests per year. 
Any usage through fire lines less than ten gallons per month is not an unauthorized use of water. 
(b)  Inspections. Inspections required under the provisions of this article shall be made by the manager, or his designee. 
(1)  Upon presentation of proper credentials, the manager, or his designee, may enter at reasonable times any building, structure or premises in the city, and any building, structure or premises which is being served by the water system of the city, to perform any duty imposed by this article. The manager, and his designees are hereby authorized and directed to enforce all provisions of this article, and are hereby vested with all police power necessary for the purpose of enforcing this article, including but not limited to the making of arrests, issuing citations, and the prosecution of any persons or entities that may be charged with any violations of this article. 
(2)  All installations of any equipment, appliance, or systems, as prescribed in this article or any other ordinance of the city, shall be subject to inspection by the manager, or his designee. 
(Ord. of 7-8-1996, § III; Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(VI)(III)) 
Sec. 58-216. - Selection of devices. 
Vacuum breakers and backflow preventers shall be selected based upon the degree of hazard and the type of cross connection. The degree of hazard is to be determined by whether or not the impurities which constitute the risk of contamination are contaminants or pollutants; and the type of cross connection is to be determined by whether or not the type of cross connection is nonpressure or pressure in nature. 
(1)  Class I installations. A double check valve assembly with flow detection meter may be utilized for fire lines with a direct connection from the city's water system to the facility's sprinkler system. All other class I installations from detection meter shall utilize a backflow preventer assembly which operates by the reduced pressure principle. All fire lines which utilize pumps, storage tanks, antifreeze, auxiliary water supplies, etc., will not be considered a direct connection system. 
(2)  Class II installations. All class II installations shall utilize a backflow preventer assembly which operates by the reduced pressure principle. 
(3)  Class III and class IV installations. All class III and IV installations may use any type of backflow preventer assemblies set forth herein. However, if the manager or his designee determines that any specific situation represents an unusual risk of contamination or pollution, the manager or his designee may require the installation of a backflow preventer assembly which operates by the reduced pressure principle. 
(4)  Cross connections, nonpressure type. This type of connection, when not protected by a minimum air gap, shall be protected by an appropriate vacuum breaker or by an appropriate backflow preventer. 
(5)  Cross connection, pressure type. This type connection shall be protected by an appropriate backflow preventer only. Neither atmospheric nonpressure type vacuum breakers shall be used on pressure type cross connections. 
(6)  Lawn sprinkler systems. Because lawn sprinkler systems serve an environment that is open to the atmosphere, it is not classified under this article as a pressure type cross connection. Due to the special nature of the installation, however, it is mandated that all such systems which are connected the city water system shall have at minimum as backflow protection, a double check valve assembly, in order to preclude the risk of herbicides and other chemicals which may be injected into said lawn sprinkler systems being pulled back into the city system. 
(7)  Accepted materials for devices. Vacuum breakers shall be bronze. Backflow preventers, including accessories, components and fittings in sizes two inches in diameter or less, shall be bronze with threaded connections. Backflow preventers, including accessories, components and fittings in sizes greater than two inches in diameter shall be either iron or bronze with flanged connections. 
(8)  Thermal expansion control device. A thermal expansion control device shall be used between a backflow preventer and a water heater, as described in the state plumbing code, section 1114, as amended. 
(Ord. of 7-8-1996, § IV; Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(VI)(IV)) 
Sec. 58-217. - Approval of devices. 
Vacuum breakers and backflow preventers shall be approved in accordance with the applicable standards of the American Water Works Association and the American Backflow Prevention Association. 
(Ord. of 7-8-1996, § V; Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(VI)(V)) 
Sec. 58-218. - Installation of devices. 
Vacuum breakers and backflow preventers equipped with atmospheric vents, or with relief openings, shall be so installed and so located as to prevent any vent or any relief opening from being submerged. Such breakers and preventers shall be installed in the position recommended by the manufacturer and shall be protected from freezing. 
(1)  Vacuum breaker, atmospheric type (VB-AT). These devices shall be installed at least six inches above the highest outlet or the overflow level on the nonpotable system. It shall be installed downstream of the last shutoff valve on the customer's system. 
(2)  Vacuum breaker, pressure type (VB-PT). These devices shall be installed at least 12 inches above the highest outlet or the overflow level on the nonpotable system. It shall be installed downstream of the last shutoff valve on the customer's system. 
(3)  Vacuum breaker, hose type (VB-HT). If not an integral part of a faucet or hydrant, this device shall be attached directly to the hose threads of the valve. It may not be subjected to continuous pressure, static or flowing, nor shall it be attached to a freezeless type hydrant unless it is a model specifically designed for this service. 
(4)  Backflow preventer, dual check (BFP-DUC). This device shall not be buried in earth, but may be installed below ground in a vault or meter box so as to permit ready accessibility for testing and repair. A positive shutoff valve shall be installed near the inlet side of the device and a union shall be installed on either side of said device in such a manner as to allow the flow through said device to be stopped by the shutoff valve so that the unions will allow the removal of said device without further disturbance of the customers water system. 
(5)  Backflow preventer with intermediate atmospheric vent (BFP-IAV). Installation of this device below ground is prohibited. When relief valve discharge could cause water damage, it shall be piped via an air gap, or a funnel, at the vent-relief port to a floor drain or other approved location. A positive shutoff and union shall be near the inlet and outlet side of the device. A strainer with a No. 20 mesh stainless steel screen shall be included between the inlet shutoff valve and the device. 
(6)  Backflow preventer, double check valve (BFP-DCV). This device shall not be buried in earth but may be installed below ground in a vault or meter box, provided ball valve test cocks fitted with brass plugs are used. A positive shutoff valve shall be near the inlet and outlet sides of the device, and three ball valve test cocks shall be provided on the upstream side of the inlet shutoff valve. When below ground, a union flange shall be installed near the inlet and outlet sides of the device. No intervening connection(s) shall be installed between the shutoff valves and the backflow preventer. 
(7)  Backflow preventer, reduced pressure zone (BFP-RPZ). Installation of this device below ground is prohibited. When relief discharge fro the device could cause water damage, it shall be piped via an air gap, or a funnel, at the relief port to a floor drain or other approved location. A positive shutoff valve shall be installed near the inlet and outlet sides of the device, and three approved test cocks shall be provided on the device. A fourth test cock shall be installed on the upstream side of the inlet shutoff valve. No intervening branch connections shall be allowed between the shutoff and the backflow preventer. 
(Ord. of 7-8-1996, § VI; Ord. of 2-10-1997, exh. A; Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(VI)(VI)) 
Sec. 58-219. - Additional installation requirements. 
When the reduced pressure zone device is installed in a line subject to periodic no-flow conditions, and the supply pressure on such a line is subject to fluctuations, a auxiliary directional check with soft-disc, capable of functioning in any position the backflow preventer may be installed in, shall be provided between the inlet shutoff valve and the backflow preventer head to lock the supply pressure in and prevent unnecessary discharge of water through the vent-relief port. When a water pressure reducing valve is required in the same line with the reduced pressure zone device, the auxiliary directional check will not be required, if and only if, the pressure reducing valve is located upstream of the reduced pressure zone device so as to take advantage of the check valve effect of the pressure reducing valve. 
(Ord. of 7-8-1996, § VII; Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(VI)(VII)) 
Sec. 58-220. - Maintenance and testing of devices. 
(a)  Requirements. All vacuum breakers and backflow preventers shall be maintained in working order, and shall be tested on an annual basis. Field testing and repairs shall be performed by personnel of the city or by such outside contractor approved by the manager. The customer shall keep records of the testing, maintenance and repair activities, and shall make such records available to the manager upon request. All vacuum breakers and back flow preventers shall be individually tested at the factory. Reduced pressure zone backflow preventers and double check assemblies shall be tested immediately after installation, and thereafter on an annual basis. The standard fee shall be charged by the city for all tests conducted by city personnel. 
(b)  City's duty. The manager or his designee shall have the duty to investigate all suspected violations of the provisions of this article and any suspect cross connections or suspect failures of backflow prevention devices. 
(Ord. of 7-8-1996, § VIII; Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(VI)(VIII)) 
Sec. 58-221. - Summary. 
(a)  Approved backflow prevention required. All public and all private water supply systems shall have approved protection against backflow to prevent the return of water from these systems back to the supply lines of the city water system. 
(b)  Auxiliary. All auxiliary water supply systems for fire protection, irrigation, or industrial processes shall have approved protection against backflow to prevent the return of water from these sources the same, or potentially the same, as those for potable water systems. 
(c)  General public. All consumers whose water systems are supplied from the city water system's water mains shall have approved protection against backflow at the service connection to the consumer's system, or the closest practical proximity to the service connection. 
(d)  Isolation. In addition to protection against backflow at the service connection, or entrances from other sources of supply referred to generally as containment, all cross connections (existing or potential) on the consumer's system shall have approved protection against backflow at the points of such cross connections, referred to generally as isolation. 
(e)  Thermal expansion control device. If water is heated in a distribution system, or a branch of the system, that has been closed by the installation of a backflow preventer, a pressure reducing valve or other checking devices, an approved thermal expansion control device shall be installed to limit the pressure build-up of the heated water to not more than 80 psi no-flow pressure at any fixture on the system. 
(f)  Notification of containment/isolation. Prior to containing a system, the manager, or his designee, shall give the plumbing official and the consumer proper notice of his intent to do so, along with an explanation of a closed system. He shall give the consumer a reasonable length of time to add a thermal expansion control device to his water supply system, in accordance with the appliable plumbing code, to control the resulting thermal expansion pressure buildups when his system is closed, unless an immediate hazard to health exists. 
(Ord. of 7-8-1996, § IX; Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(VI)(IX)) 
Sec. 58-222. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Termination of service; lien created by nonpayment of amounts due; interest on amounts due. In order to enforce the operation of this article, the city shall have the power and authority to enter upon the property of any user who has violated any provision of this article following due notice of the violation, to terminate the user's water and/or wastewater service in any manner deemed necessary and appropriate by the city. In the event of such termination under this section, the city shall retain all rights to collect unpaid bills or amounts owed by the terminated user according to law or other provision of this article. Such rates or charges, if not paid when due, shall constitute a lien upon the premises served. Past due amounts shall bear interest at the same rate as would unpaid ad valorem taxes. 
(b)  Civil liabilities and penalties. Any person who intentionally or negligently violates any provisions contained in this article shall be liable civilly to the city. Said civil liability may be in a sum not to exceed $10,000.00 for each day in which such violation occurs. 
(c)  Injunctive relief. If any person violates the provisions of this article, the city may commence an action for appropriate legal and/or equitable relief including injunctive relief, in the appropriate court of competent jurisdiction. 
(d)  Consent orders. Consent orders may be utilized by the manager to enforce the provisions contained in this article. A consent order may be issued to any person, business or company who violates any provisions of this article. The consent order shall be an agreement between the city and the entity in violation that shall operate as follows: 
(1)  The city shall agree not to prosecute under the law relative to the particular violation or violations being considered if the terms and conditions of the consent order are complied with by the entity in violation. 
(2)  A schedule including various terms and conditions, as necessary for the entity in violation to achieve compliance shall be provided. 
(3)  A monetary payment of an amount commensurate with the nature and magnitude of the violation may be stipulated in the consent order. This monetary payment shall be from the entity in violation to the city and shall have the legal effect of consideration provided in exchange for the city's covenant not to sue or prosecute on the violation or violations stipulated in the consent order. 
(4)  Any party to any consent order shall agree that any such consent order may be filed with the county superior court along with pleadings seeking to make such consent order an order of the superior court or enforceable as such court order in any subsequent enforcement action which may be necessary. 
(e)  Criminal sanctions and fines. Any person found guilty of violating any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not less than $50.00 and not more than $500.00, and every day such violation exists shall constitute a separate offense and be punishable as herein set out. Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to abridge, limit, or otherwise impair the right of any person to maintain any action or other appropriate proceeding for damages or other relief on account of injuries to persons or property. 
(Ord. of 7-8-1996, § XI; Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(VI)(XI)) 
Secs. 58-223—58-254. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - LARGE LIFT STATIONS AND FORCE MAINS 

Sec. 58-255. - Specifications. 
(a)  Large lift stations are those with pumps greater than three horsepower or that serve more than two residential or commercial units. There are two categories of large sewage lift stations associated with the city's sewage system, as follows: 
(1)  Inside city. All large sewage lift stations located within the city limits will be dedicated to and owned and operated by the city so long as all requirements of the city are met. Until such time as all the city's requirements have been met and the city has accepted ownership of the lift station in writing, it shall be the sole responsibility of the developer/applicant to operate and maintain the lift station. 
(2)  Outside city. Except as may be expressly approved by the city council on a case-by-case basis, all large lift stations located outside of the city limits shall be owned, operated and maintained by the owner/applicant, and the city shall have no responsibility for the operation thereof. 
(b)  Special requirements. 
(1)  Lift stations will be permitted only when gravity sewer is unavailable to the property being served. 
(2)  Except as may be approved on a case-by-case basis by the city council, the owner/applicant shall furnish and install the entire lift station/force main system. The system will be designed by the owner/applicant's engineer (designer) licensed to practice engineering in the state. The design must be reviewed and approved by the city. The designer shall consult with the city's engineer during the design of the system. 
(3)  The designer shall locate the lift station to drain the largest possible subbasin. The city's engineer shall approve the location prior to final design to ensure proper location. 
(4)  Generally a pump station will not be allowed to be installed downstream from an existing pump station with its flow going to the existing pump station. The city may, at its discretion, require that a gravity line be installed to carry flow from the existing pump station to the proposed pump station thus eliminating the existing pump station. 
(5)  The merging together of two or more force mains into one force main is referred to as manifolding. The manifolding of force mains is discouraged. However, in the event that manifolding is determined to be the only practical solution to sewage transmission, for all lift stations which connect to an existing force main, the designer must show by proper engineering calculations that the capacities of all related force mains and lift stations in the system will not be exceeded considering the reasonably anticipated worst case conditions. These engineering calculations must be reviewed and approved by the city engineer. 
(c)  Site development plans and profiles must show the following: 
(1)  Gravity system and connection to lift station; 
(2)  Force main design showing connection to existing system; 
(3)  Design calculations, including pump curves also showing the pump and system head curves; 
(4)  Plan of the subbasin which drains to the lift station to include contours and projected flow calculations for the entire subbasin; 
(5)  Details of the lift station installation including grades, materials of construction, control systems, etc. Plan and profile views are required; 
(6)  Electrical supply and control diagrams showing all electrical requirements as well as control logic diagram (or a written description of the control logic); 
(7)  Site plan showing finished grade contour lines (two-foot intervals) in and around lift station and access road and all existing and proposed utilities. 
(d)  Large lift stations shall be below grade with duplex (two) submersible pumps operating in the lead-lag configuration such that the pumps alternate after each pump cycle. The lift stations shall be made of concrete, fiberglass, or other structurally suitable, noncorrosive material. Each lift station shall have an above grade access hatch of a size, configuration and elevation that is readily accessible for a human being and suitable for easy installation and removal of the pumps. The hatch shall be designed and located such that surface water flow cannot enter the lift station. The pump manufacturer shall be approved by the city. All pumps shall be able to pass a three-inch diameter solid except those pumps serving individual commercial or residential units shall be able to pass a one-inch diameter solid. 
(e)  Provide fresh water (20 psi minimum) for wash down (50-foot of three-fourths-inch hose supplied with nozzle installed), with back flow preventer installed in accordance with the city's backflow prevention program. The water meter must be set at the edge of the right-of-way. 
(f)  Large lift stations with pumps exceeding three hp shall have the following (unless otherwise approved by the city): 
(1)  Fenced area (25 feet by 25 feet minimum) eight-foot-high fabric nine gauge wire (chainlink type) with top rails and bottom tension wires; three strands barbed wire at top on angled extension arms; posts in three-foot concrete minimum ten-inch diameter spaced ten feet apart; 
(2)  Fourteen-foot wide gate on four-inch diameter posts; 
(3)  High pressure sodium security light on 20-foot pressure treated pole with automatic eye; 
(4)  The wetwell shall be sized to prevent excessive cycling of the pumps. Starts shall be limited to one shart per ten minutes unless otherwise recommended by the pump manufacturer. Size shall be as recommended by the pump supplier and shall be approved by the city. Minimum six-foot diameter wetwell for suction lift pumps. Hatch doors shall be sized by the pump supplier to allow adequate clearance to easily remove the pumps; 
(5)  The force main must have a cutoff valve positioned after the check valve pit. On long force mains the city may require additional in-line valves to isolate sections of the force main in the vent of a pipe failure. 
(Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(VII)(A)) 
Sec. 58-256. - Electrical specifications. 
(a)  Prior to any approval, the appropriate power company or the city engineer must notify the city that three phase power and voltage is available to the site. In the event that three-phase power is not readily available to the site, the developer may be permitted to utilize a phase converter upon submittal of a letter showing that the cost to install three-phase service is excessive. Approval for the use of a phase converted will be granted by the city based on the specific site conditions. Single phase power will be allowed only for lift stations with pumps less than three horsepower serving individual commercial or residential units. 
(b)  Pump stations installed in developments with underground power will be permitted to utilize three-phase 208 voltage for stations with up to 15 horsepower motors. 
(c)  All aboveground conduit work shall be galvanized rigid conduit (IMC). 
(d)  Switching gear (transfer switch, breakers, etc.) shall be mounted in panel box made of either stainless steel or aluminum minimum of one-eighths-inch thickness of NEMA 4 rating with hinged door with lock. Panel is to set on legs mounted to concrete base, conduit stubs to enter at bottom of panel and to be set in the concrete base for support. 
(e)  No conduit runs or junction boxes are to be installed inside or on top of wet well. 
(f)  Lift stations shall have factory installed hour meters to show pump's running time to the tenth of an hour. 
(g)  Phase converter, when utilized, shall be of the rotary type; manufactured by Kay Industries, distributed by Power Systems Engineering. Stationary type, such as add-a-phase, will not be allowed. 
(h)  The electrical system shall include the means to send a signal to the telemetry system that the incoming power has failed or has lost one phase. 
(i)  A phone dialer shall be provided. 
(j)  An emergency generator or power supplied from two independent sources with automatic switchover capability. All gasoline or diesel powered emergency generators shall have secondary containment to protect against releases of fuel. 
(Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(VII)(B)) 
Sec. 58-257. - Ownership. 
Unless otherwise expressly approved by the city, the developer shall maintain ownership and responsibility of all large sewage lift stations. 
(Res. of 11-13-2006(2), exh. A(VII)(D)) 
Secs. 58-258—58-279. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - WATER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-280. - Water usage policy for cleanup and inspections. 
(a)  The city will charge a flat rate, $25.00 nonrefundable fee for contractors, property owners, inspectors, and potential tenants for the use of the city's water if there is not an active account registered with the city's utility department. 
(b)  Persons who request the water meter to be on and pay the required deposit will be able to clean and/or inspect the property for a period of three days. 
(c)  Water usage that exceeds 500 gallons will be billed a minimum water bill in addition to the $25.00. 
(Policy of 4-12-2004) 
Sec. 58-281. - Unlawful for unauthorized persons to tap or open mains or lines. 
It shall be unlawful for any person other than an employee of the city in the performance of his duties as such, or a person having secured a prior permit from the city, to tap into or make any opening in connection with the water mains or waterlines of the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 1970, § 6-505) 
Secs. 58-282—58-310. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WATER CONSERVATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2016-18, adopted Nov. 21, 2016, amended Div. 2 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Div. 2, §§ 58-311—58-324, pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 

Sec. 58-311. - Authority and purpose. 
The city, under its powers pursuant to state law, has adopted this division to protect the public health and welfare. This division implements the city's authority to impose water use restrictions, conditioned upon a restricted water use period declared by the city pursuant to the terms of this division or a declared drought response level implementation declared by the state pursuant to chapter 391-3-30 of the rules of the state department of natural resources, environmental protection division, entitled Drought Management (Ga. Comp. Rules and Regs. 391-3-30-.01 et seq.) 
(Ord. No. 2016-18, 11-21-2016) 
Sec. 58-312. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Address means the house number (a number or alphanumeric designation) that, together with the street name, describes a physical location of a specific property. 
Declared drought response level (DDRL) means one of three levels of drought that may be declared by the state department of natural resources based on the severity of drought conditions, with one being the least severe and three being the most severe, as provided in Ga. Comp. Rules and Regs. 391-3-30-.01 et seq., pertaining to outdoor water use. 
Division means the environmental protection division of the department of natural resources. 
Even-numbered address means a house number ending with the number 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, or no house number. 
Odd-numbered address means a house number ending with the number 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9. 
Outdoor watering means any watering of decorative lawns, trees or shrubbery or ornamental fountains, or uses defined in GA. Comp Rules and Regulations of the State of Georgia 391-3-30. 
Water users means all persons or municipalities using water from any public water source irrespective of that person's responsibility for billing purposes for use of the water. 
(Ord. No. 2016-18, 11-21-2016) 
Sec. 58-313. - Declaration of period of restricted water use. 
The mayor or city manager shall declare a period of restricted water use in either of two circumstances: 
(1)  State DDRL announcement. In the event of imposition by the division of a DDRL encompassing the geographical area of the city's water service area or any part thereof, the mayor or city manager shall declare a water emergency and the level thereof under the approval of the division. Upon the declaration, the restrictions of this division shall apply to all water use within the city's water service area until the restrictions are lifted by the mayor or the city council; provided, however, that the restrictions shall remain in full force and effect until any state outdoor watering ban has been lifted. 
(2)  Local declaration. In the event of prolonged drought, failure of equipment, or any other factor that substantially affects or may affect the supply of water to the city and the city's water users, the mayor or city manager may declare an emergency and the level thereof with an approved variance from the division. Upon the declaration, the restrictions of this division shall apply to all water use within the city until the restrictions are lifted. The declaration should be, where appropriate, conditioned on the identification of an emergency or water shortage by the city personnel, county personnel, state agency, federal agency, or the state governor. 
(Ord. No. 2016-18, 11-21-2016) 
Sec. 58-314. - Notice of declaration. 
Upon declaration of a period of restricted water use, the mayor or city manager shall notify all users through news releases to the media, through notices mailed to all users, or through such other means as the mayor or city manager shall deem expedient and appropriate. Notice shall be given as soon as practical after the declaration of a period of restricted water use is made. 
(Ord. No. 2016-18, 11-21-2016) 
Sec. 58-315. - Watering methods. 
During a period of restricted water use of any level, outdoor watering is restricted to bucket, can or handheld hose watering with automatic shutoff nozzle. The use of automatic sprinkler systems is prohibited, except watering of newly installed landscaping as permitted herein and except testing of a newly installed or newly repaired sprinkler system by a commercial enterprise engaged in the installation or repair of lawn irrigation systems. 
(Ord. No. 2016-18, 11-21-2016) 
Sec. 58-315.01. - Pre-drought mitigation strategies. 
(a)  During non-drought periods, irrigation outdoors for purposes of planting, growing, managing, or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs, or other plants, shall be in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 12-5-7(a.1)(1) and (2). 
(1)  Persons may irrigate outdoors daily for purposes of planting, growing, managing, or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs, or other plants only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m. 
(2)  Subdivision (a)(1) shall not create any limitation upon the following outdoor uses: 
a.  Commercial agricultural operations as defined in O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3; 
b.  Capture and reuse of cooling system condensate or storm water in compliance with applicable local ordinances and state guidelines; 
c.  Reuse of gray water in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 31-3-5.2 and applicable board of health regulations adopted pursuant thereto; 
d.  Use of reclaimed waste water by a designated user from a system permitted by the Environmental Protection Division of the department to provide reclaimed waste water; 
e.  Irrigation of personal food gardens; 
f.  Irrigation of new and replanted plant, seed, or turf in landscapes, golf courses, or sports turf fields during installation and for a period of 30 days immediately following the date of installation; 
g.  Drip irrigation or irrigation using soaker hoses; 
h.  Hand watering with a hose with automatic cutoff or handheld container; 
i.  Use of water withdrawn from private water wells or surface water by an owner or operator of property if such well or surface water is on said property; 
j.  Irrigation of horticultural crops held for sale, resale, or installation; 
k.  Irrigation of athletic fields, golf courses, or public turf grass recreational areas; 
l.  Installation, maintenance, or calibration of irrigation systems; or 
m.  Hydroseeding. 
(3)  Subsection (a)(1) shall not create any limitation upon outdoor water uses for purposes other than planting, growing, managing, or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs, or other plants. 
(b)  The state has already made, and continues to make, extensive investments in water efficiency since conservation measures play such an important role in water stewardship. Therefore, with the exception of the outdoor irrigation requirements in O.C.G.A. § 12-5-7(a.1)(1) and (2) and the Drought Contingency Plans and Water Conservation Plans required under Rules 391-3-2-.04(11), 391-3-6-.07(4)(b) 8, and 391-3-6-.07(4)(b) 9, this rule does not repeat or modify any existing predrought mitigation strategy or create any new predrought mitigation strategies. 
(Ord. No. 2016-18, 11-21-2016) 
Sec. 58-316. - Drought response level 1. 
Permittees that are public water systems shall implement a public information campaign that shall include, at a minimum, public notice regarding drought conditions and drought specific public-service messages in one or more of the following ways: newspaper advertisements, bill inserts, website homepage, social media, and notices in public libraries. 
(Ord. No. 2016-18, 11-21-2016) 
Sec. 58-317. - Level two restrictions. 
During drought response level 2, permittees shall implement all drought response level 1 measures plus the following additional drought response level 2 measures: 
(1)  General outdoor watering. Outdoor irrigation for purposes of planting, growing, managing, or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs, or other plants, as described in Rule 391-3-30-.03(1)(a), shall be limited to two days a week on an odd-even schedule. Even-numbered addresses may irrigate on Wednesday and Saturday between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m. Odd numbered addresses may irrigate on Thursday and Sunday between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m. "Even-numbered address" means an address number ending with the number 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, or the site does not have a numbered address. "Odd-numbered address" means an address ending with the number 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9. 
(2)  Specific categories of outdoor water use . The outdoor water uses listed in Rule 391-3-30-.03(1)(b) shall be allowed. 
(3)  The following outdoor water uses shall not be allowed, except as provided below: 
a.  Washing hard surfaces such as streets, gutters, sidewalks and driveways, except when necessary for public health and safety; 
b.  Using water for ornamental purposes, such as fountains, reflecting pools, and waterfalls; 
c.  Use of fire hydrants, except for the purposes of firefighting, public health, safety, or flushing; 
d.  Washing vehicles, such as cars, boats, trailers, motorbikes, airplanes, or golf carts; 
e.  Non-commercial washing, or pressure washing, of buildings or structures, except for immediate fire protection; and 
f.  Charity, or non-commercial fund-raiser, car washes. 
(Ord. No. 2016-18, 11-21-2016) 
Sec. 58-318. - Level three restrictions. 
During drought response level 3, permittees shall implement all drought response level 1 and 2 measures plus the following additional drought response level 3 measures: 
(1)  General outdoor watering. Outdoor irrigation for purposes of planting, growing, managing, or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs, or other plants, as described in Rule 391-3-30-.03(1)(a), is not permitted. 
(2)  Specific categories of outdoor water use. The outdoor water uses listed in Rule 391-3-30-.03(1)(b) shall be allowed, subject to the following additional requirements: 
a.  Irrigation of personal food gardens shall be conducted between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m., unless done using drip irrigation or soaker hoses. Irrigation of personal food gardens using drip irrigation or soaker hoses may be done at any time; 
b.  Hand watering with a hose with automatic cutoff or handheld container may be conducted between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m.; 
c.  Irrigation of athletic fields or public turf grass recreational areas may be conducted between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m., subject to the two days a week odd-even schedule described in drought response level 2; 
d.  Irrigation of golf courses shall be conducted in accordance with the "Golf Irrigation Prediction and Estimation Worksheet" and only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m., provided, however, irrigation of golf course greens may occur at any time of day; 
e.  Use of reclaimed waste water by a designated user from a system permitted by the division to provide reclaimed waste water shall not be allowed for general outdoor watering as described in Rule 391-3-30-.03(1)(a). It shall be allowed for any use described in Rule 391-3-30-.03(1)(b) subject to the limitations in Rule 391-3-30-.07(4)(b); 
f.  Installation, maintenance, or calibration of irrigation systems is allowed, provided that it is done by professional landscapers or golf course superintendents. 
(Ord. No. 2016-18, 11-21-2016) 
Sec. 58-319. - Drought response strategies. 
(a)  Public information campaign that goes significantly beyond the minimum notice and public service messages associated with drought response level 1; 
(b)  Reduce system pressure, unless such reduction would create unsafe water supply conditions; 
(c)  Pool cover requirements; 
(d)  Implement a drought surcharge program, or tiered conservation rates, that satisfy the criteria of this rule; 
(e)  Suspension of street cleaning program(s); 
(f)  Implement, or accelerate, leak detection and repair program(s); 
(g)  Impose monetary penalties or terminate water services to customers to reduce outdoor water waste due to excessive application, outdoor leaks, improper irrigation, or other similar reasons. 
(Ord. No. 2016-18, 11-21-2016) 
Sec. 58-320. - Professional exemptions. 
The following commercial outdoor water uses are exempt from the outdoor water use restrictions of this rule: 
(1)  Pressure washing; 
(2)  Permanent car wash facility, provided that it is connected to a sanitary sewer system of a political subdivision or local government authority or recycles used wash water; 
(3)  Construction sites; 
(4)  Watering-in of pesticides and herbicides on turf; and 
(5)  Other activities essential to daily business. 
(Ord. No. 2016-18, 11-21-2016) 
Sec. 58-321. - Application for waiver. 
Any water user that considers the restrictions imposed during a period of restricted water use to adversely affect their livelihood, health or sanitation, may make written application for a waiver. Any such application should be directed to the attention of the mayor or city manager who shall make a determination regarding waiver within five business days of receipt of the application. The determination of the mayor or city manager shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 2016-18, 11-21-2016) 
Sec. 58-322. - Issuance of written warnings to violators. 
Persons violating water use restrictions as provided herein shall be given one warning in writing prior to the issuance of a citation, unless: 
(1)  The period of restricted water use is declared in response to a DDRL imposed by the state and applicable in the geographical limits of the city; or 
(2)  The declaration of a period of restricted water use specifically provides that no warnings will be given. 
(Ord. No. 2016-18, 11-21-2016) 
Sec. 58-323. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Every police officer of the city shall, in connection with his duties imposed by law, diligently enforce the provisions of this division, or any provision of any ordinance adopted pursuant to this division, or any written order of the mayor and council issued pursuant to this division. 
(b)  The mayor and council or the city's designated representative shall have the authority to enforce the provisions of this division, or any provision of any ordinance adopted pursuant to this division, or any written order of the mayor and council issued pursuant to this division, by the discontinuance of water service in the event of a violation hereof. 
(Ord. No. 2016-18, 11-21-2016) 
Sec. 58-324. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate a provision of this division, or any provision of any ordinance adopted pursuant to this division, or any written order by the mayor and council or the city's designated representative, issued pursuant to this division, or shall withdraw water from the water supply system of the city for uses prohibited, or in an amount in excess of limitations placed thereon by any such ordinance or order of the mayor and council, or the city's designated representative, shall be penalized as follows: 

 
(b)  Each such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation of this division, or failure to comply with any such ordinance or order, is committed or continued. 
(Ord. No. 2016-18, 11-21-2016) 
Secs. 58-325—58-353. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - METERS 

Sec. 58-354. - Water meter installation. 
The installation of water meters to monitor the water and sewer consumption in a multiple-unit building shall be pursuant to the requirements of this division. 
(1)  Installation of one water meter (one meter to serve multiple units). The owner is responsible for all applicable tap and connection fees. Fees are assessed per entry doorway and not per meter. If one water meter is installed to monitor the water and sewer consumption in more than one unit in a multiple-unit building, the owner of the building must register the water and sewer services in the name of the owner, and the owner will be billed and shall be responsible for payment of all water and sewer charges. Once the amount of connections have been determined, the same amount of users will be billed monthly to the owner of the building. Sufficient outside curbstop valves for each unit must be installed so that the utility services can be independently shut off without disrupting utility services to the other units in the building Sewer tap and connection fees are assessed per entry and not per meter. 
(2)  Installation of multiple water meters (meter per unit). The owner is responsible for all applicable tap and connection fees. Fees are assessed per meter. If multiple water meters are installed to monitor the water and sewer consumption in a multiple-unit building, the owner of the building must comply with one of the following requirements for the installation: 
a.  If the water and sewer services for the building are registered in the name of the owner, the owner will be billed and shall be responsible for payment of all water and sewer charges; or 
b.  The water and sewer services for each unit in the building may be registered in the name of the tenant, provided the owner agrees to install and maintain in working order, at the owner's expense, an outside curbstop valve for each water meter installed so that the utility services to a unit can be independently shut off without disrupting utility services to the other units in the building. 
(Ord. of 11-5-2007, § I) 
Sec. 58-355. - Existing service. 
(a)  Existing water and sewer services for any multiple-unit building that does not have sufficient outside curbstop valves for each water meter installed so that the utility services can be independently shut off without disrupting utility services to the other units in the building may be billed to the individual tenants provided that the water and sewer charges were billed to the individual tenants prior to the adoption of this division and have been continuously billed to the individual tenants since November 2001. 
(b)  If an existing tenant moves from the building, the water and sewer services may be registered in the name of the new tenant provided the new tenant pays a deposit for water and sewer services as established by the current water and sewer rate ordinance. 
(c)  Remodeling, change of use, etc., may require the owner of the building to install outside curbstop valves for each water meter installed. 
(Ord. of 11-5-2007, § II) 
Sec. 58-356. - Access to premises. 
The owner of a multiple-unit building and/or tenant shall grant employees of the city public works department immediate access to each water meter when necessary for the purpose of inspecting, repairing, removing, or replacing the meter. 
(Ord. of 11-5-2007, § III) 
Sec. 58-357. - Penalties. 
Penalties shall apply for all unauthorized water and sewer connections. The penalty amount will be assessed at two times the amount of the tap and connection fees for water and sewer which are effective on the date of the discovery of the unauthorized connections. 
(Ord. of 11-5-2007, § IV) 
Chapter 60 - VEGETATION[1] 
Footnotes:
