State Law reference— Plant disease, pest control and pesticides, O.C.G.A. § 2-7-1 et seq.; forest resources and other plant life, O.C.G.A. § 12-6-1 et seq.; timber harvesting and removal requirements, O.C.G.A. § 12-6-23 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 60-1—60-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WEEDS 

Sec. 60-19. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Weeds includes, but is not limited to, jimson, burdock, ragweed, thistle, cocklebur, dandelion, or other unsightly growths of a like kind. 
Sec. 60-20. - Prohibited growth. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner or resident of any lot, area, or place located within the city to permit any weeds, grass, or deleterious, unhealthful growths to obtain a height exceeding 12 inches on such property. Weed growth prohibited by this section shall be a public nuisance subject to abatement as set forth herein. 
Sec. 60-21. - Violation constitutes nuisance. 
It shall be a nuisance per se for the owner or occupant of any lot, tract or parcel of land or premises in the city to permit the growth thereon of weeds or vegetative undergrowth of a nature or density so as to violate the provisions of this article or so as to endanger the public health, safety or welfare, or so as to block public roads, streets, alleys or sidewalks. 
Sec. 60-22. - Notice to remove. 
It shall be the duty of the city police chief or designee to notify, in writing, the owner or occupant of any premises upon which weeds or other prohibited flora permitted to grow in violation of the provisions of this article that such growths must be removed, cut or destroyed within ten days from the date of such notice. Notice shall be by registered mail, addressed to said owner or occupant, at his last known address, and by posting on the subject property. Notice shall be complete upon posting. 
Sec. 60-23. - Abatement. 
Upon the failure, neglect, or refusal of any owner or occupant so notified to remove, cut, or destroy such weeds or other unsightly growths within the designated time period, the appropriate city departments and employees are authorized and empowered to provide for the removal, cutting, or destroying of such growths by or for the city. 
Sec. 60-24. - Costs of abatement. 
The actual cost of such weed removal shall be assessed against the property owner upon whose premises the work is done and a statement of the sums due shall be provided to the owner in the same manner as provided for notices to remove. In the event the bill for such charges remains unpaid ten days after it has been rendered, shall become a lien upon the premises enforceable in the same manner as provided for the collection of unpaid taxes. 
Secs. 60-25—60-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TREES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 60-51. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Crown spread means the distance measured across the greatest diameter of a plant. 
Park tree means either evergreen or deciduous trees or shrubs located on land designated as public park land. Public park land shall be land owned or leased by the city and used for public park purposes. 
Shade tree means any self-supporting woody plant of a species that is normally well-shaped, well-branched and well-foliated which normally grows to an overall height of at least 35 feet and normally develops an average mature crown spread greater than 30 feet. 
Small tree means either evergreen or deciduous trees or shrubs, which do not normally exceed 12 feet in height at maturity. No tree which exceeds 12 feet in height shall be classified as a small tree. 
Street tree means either evergreen or deciduous trees or shrubs located on land lying within the public right-of-way on either side of all public streets, roads, avenues or ways within the city. 
(Ord. of 12-10-2003, § V(a)—(c)) 
Sec. 60-52. - Board to maintain list of recommended species. 
The city tree board shall develop and maintain a list of species of street, park, shade and small trees which said tree board recommends for the planting of new trees within the city. 
(Ord. of 12-10-2003, § V(d)) 
Sec. 60-53. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person, legal or natural, found guilty of violation any provision of this article shall be subject to penalties as provided in section 1-18. 
(b)  Action pursuant to any provision of this article shall not be a bar to the enforcement of this article by injunction or other appropriate remedy, and the city, acting by and through the city building inspector, or other duly authorized individual, shall have the power to institute and maintain in the name of the city any and all such enforcement proceedings. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to abridge, limit, or otherwise impair the right of any person to institute and maintain any action or other appropriate proceeding for damages or other relief on account of injuries to persons or property. 
(Ord. of 12-10-2003, § XIII) 
Secs. 60-54—60-79. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TREE BOARD 

Sec. 60-80. - Creation and establishment. 
There is hereby created and established a city tree board, which shall consist of five members, who shall be residents of the city, and who shall be appointed by the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. of 12-10-2003, § I) 
Sec. 60-81. - Term of office. 
The term of office for each the members of the city tree board shall be one year. In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member of said board, the mayor and council shall appoint a successor to fill the unexpired portion of the term of such member. 
(Ord. of 12-10-2003, § II) 
Sec. 60-82. - Compensation. 
Members of the tree board shall serve without compensation, except for such per-meeting stipends as may be authorized by the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. of 12-10-2003, § III) 
Sec. 60-83. - Duties, responsibilities, and operation. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility of the tree board to study and investigate the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal and/or disposition of trees and shrubs in parks, along public streets and in other public areas, and to periodically report such studies and investigations to the mayor and city council. The tree board, when requested by the mayor and city council, shall consider, investigate, make findings, report and recommend upon any specific matter or question coming within the scope of its work. All such studies, investigations, considerations, findings, reports and/or recommendations shall be advisory only. The mayor and council shall designate the chairman of said tree board. The tree board shall: 
(1)  By majority vote elect all other officers it deems necessary and appropriate; 
(2)  By majority vote adopt such rules governing the conduct of its meetings which are not contrary to law; and 
(3)  Keep minutes of its meetings. 
(b)  A majority of the members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Ord. of 12-10-2003, § IV) 
Sec. 60-84. - Interference, etc., with city tree board prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the city tree board, or any of its members and/or agents, while engaged in conducting the activities of authorized by this division. 
(Ord. of 12-10-2003, § XII) 
Secs. 60-85—60-111. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TREE REGULATIONS 

Sec. 60-112. - Distance from street corners and fire hydrants. 
No tree (whether street tree, park tree, shade tree or small tree) shall be planted or otherwise located closer than 20 feet from the intersection of any public street with another public street or with a designated private street, as measured from point of intersection of the nearest paved surfaces of such streets. However, shrubs of less than three feet in height are allowed to be located not less than four feet from such intersections. No tree (whether street tree, park tree, shade tree or small tree) shall be planted or otherwise located closer than ten feet from any fire hydrant. This section shall apply only to the planting and/or location of new trees and shall not be interpreted to require the removal of trees in the ground on the date of adoption of the ordinance from which this division is derived. This section shall not apply to the central business district of the city. 
(Ord. of 12-10-2003, § VI) 
Sec. 60-113. - Utilities. 
No tree, other than a tree meeting the definition of a small tree as set forth in this division, shall be planted or located under or within ten lateral feet of any overhead utility wire, or over or within five lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer line, power line, or other utility. This section shall apply only to the planting or location of new trees and shall not be interpreted to require the removal of trees in the ground on the date of adoption of the ordinance from which this division is derived. 
(Ord. of 12-10-2003, § VII) 
Sec. 60-114. - Public tree care. 
(a)  The city shall have the right, power and authority to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the boundaries and rights-of-way of the streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares, and public grounds of the city, as may be necessary to insure public safely and to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares, and public grounds of the city. 
(b)  The city shall have the right, power and authority to remove, or cause or order to be removed, any tree or part thereof within the boundaries and rights-of-way of the streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares, and public grounds of the city, which tree or any part thereof: 
(1)  Is in an unsafe condition; 
(2)  By reason of its nature or condition, is injurious to sewers, electrical power lines, gas lines, water lines, or other public improvements and/or the structural integrity of any public street or sidewalk; and/or 
(3)  Is infected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. 
(Ord. of 12-10-2003, § VIII) 
Sec. 60-115. - Tree topping. 
It shall be unlawful, as a normal practice, for any person or city department to top any street tree, park tree, or other tree on public property. Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes or certain trees under utility wires where other pruning practices are impractical shall be exempted from this section. 
(Ord. of 12-10-2003, § IX) 
Sec. 60-116. - Pruning corner clearance trees on private property. 
Every owner of any tree overhanging any public street or right-of-way within the city shall prune the branches of such tree so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any streetlamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of eight feet above the surface of the street or sidewalk. Said owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs, which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of lights along the street from a streetlight or interferes with the visibility of any traffic control device or sign. 
(Ord. of 12-10-2003, § X) 
Sec. 60-117. - Dead or diseased tree removal on private property. 
(a)  The city shall have the right, power and authority to cause the removal of any dead or diseased tree located on private property within the city, when such tree: 
(1)  Constitutes a hazard to life; 
(2)  Constitutes a hazard to property; and/or 
(3)  Harbors insects or disease which constitute a potential threat to other trees within the city. Diseased or dangerous trees constitute nuisances per se. 
(b)  The city shall have the right, power and authority to take such action immediately in those instances which present a clear and immediate danger of substantial harm to persons and/or property. In all other instances, the city may initiate action to have such tree removed under the applicable provisions of the nuisance provisions of article IV of chapter 36, as now or hereafter amended. 
(Ord. of 12-10-2003, § XI) 
Sec. 60-118. - Buffer and landscaping requirements. 
The city has adopted, as stated in chapter 64, Standard Development Specifications, April 2002, that include specifications with regard to tree and shrub buffers and other landscaping requirements. The adopted specifications shall be applicable to vegetation within the city to the extent set forth therein. A copy of the adopted specifications are available in the office of the city clerk.
